The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Mid-levels and senior associates will probably receive increased headhunter activity but most of us love working here and know that we trade being a compensation leader for flexible hours, reasonable partners, and a low leverage ratio.

That’s what gets obscured in the mad dash of salary news. With great compensation comes great billable responsibility, and firms that pay the maximum expect the maximum out of their lawyers. And firms that reach to join the elite tier may find themselves expecting more than the maximum out of their lawyers. While there are firms that expect associates to work all hours of the day and night and still take home less, when a firm is willing to embrace some flexibility — it’s still hard work, mind you — for slightly less pay, that’s perfectly fine. When I made my own lateral move years ago, I knew I was trading about $10K/year for the privilege of routinely leaving the office between 7 and 9 instead of between 12 and 2. Not only is that acceptable, the market actually needs firms like that or talented lawyers will slip out of the profession because they just can’t handle round the clock availability.

Congratulations to Steptoe & Johnson on navigating the difficult waters of balancing salary and workload.

# Biglaw Associate Has Major Bone To Pick With Morgan Stanley's GC Over Office Return Demands
## Perhaps this wasn't the best thing to draw a line in the sand about....
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJuly 23, 2021 at 3:15 PMJuly 23, 2021 at 1:36 PM
7
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/biglaw-associate-has-major-bone-to-pick-with-morgan-stanleys-gc-over-office-return-demands/&text=Biglaw%20Associate%20Has%20Major%20Bone%20To%20Pick%20With%20Morgan%20Stanley’s%20GC%20Over%20Office%20Return%20Demands)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/biglaw-associate-has-major-bone-to-pick-with-morgan-stanleys-gc-over-office-return-demands/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/biglaw-associate-has-major-bone-to-pick-with-morgan-stanleys-gc-over-office-return-demands/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
He could have used his platform to do something that [would] really make a difference, like promoting diversity or doing away with the billable hour. Instead, he makes a big deal about how we should be chained to our desk. Doesn’t he realize what we’ve been through this year?

— An anonymous third-year associate at a New York Biglaw firm, in [comments](https://news.bloomberglaw.com/business-and-practice/real-men-go-into-the-office-the-world-according-to-morgan-stanleys-gc) given to Bloomberg Law’s Vivia Chen, regarding Morgan Stanley GC Eric Grossman’s [implied mandate that lawyers return to the office](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/we-need-all-lawyers-in-the-office-says-bank-definitely-not-freaking-out-about-commercial-real-estate-portfolio/), lest they lose the bank’s business.

# An Independence Day Lesson In Interviewing
## A review of some OCI tips.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJuly 2, 2019 at 6:42 PMJuly 2, 2019 at 2:00 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/07/an-independence-day-lesson-in-interviewing/&text=An%20Independence%20Day%20Lesson%20In%20Interviewing)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/07/an-independence-day-lesson-in-interviewing/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/07/an-independence-day-lesson-in-interviewing/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(MEHDI FEDOUACH/AFP/Getty Images)

Joe and Elie are off for the Independence Day holiday but wanted to leave you with something to listen to while you enjoy your holiday. Last year, we spoke with Vanderbilt Law School’s Associate Director of Career Services Nick Alexiou to discuss the on-campus interviewing process. A good guide for those of you preparing for the interview of your lives.

# Biglaw Firm Defends Firing Of Widower, Noting 'Sadness And Grief Are Not Disabilities'
## The former partner alleges a 'toxic' environment.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onMay 20, 2022 at 11:44 AMMay 23, 2022 at 12:06 PM
164
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/05/biglaw-firm-defends-firing-of-widower-noting-sadness-and-grief-are-not-disabilities/&text=Biglaw%20Firm%20Defends%20Firing%20Of%20Widower,%20Noting%20‘Sadness%20And%20Grief%20Are%20Not%20Disabilities’)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/05/biglaw-firm-defends-firing-of-widower-noting-sadness-and-grief-are-not-disabilities/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/05/biglaw-firm-defends-firing-of-widower-noting-sadness-and-grief-are-not-disabilities/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
A former partner in the London office of White & Case,[ Michael Wistow](https://www.linkedin.com/in/michael-wistow-55752339/?originalSubdomain=uk), has accused his former firm of being a “toxic environment,” saying he was fired from the firm when he suffered mental health issues following his wife’s death from cancer. The former co-head of the EMEA tax practice sued the firm in a London employment tribunal alleging disability discrimination, saying his anxiety and depression following the death of his wife was a mental impairment.

As [reported by](https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-05-19/-toxic-london-law-firm-accused-of-forcing-out-grieving-lawyer) Bloomberg, Wistow alleges in lieu of support for his bereavement, he dealt with a problematic atmosphere:

Wistow said that the symptoms of his poor mental health led to “a substantial adverse effect on my ability to carry out day to day activities,” but instead of being offered support during this time, he endured a “toxic environment,” according to a statement prepared for a hearing this week. 

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
He also compared the culture at White & Case to other Biglaw firms and finds that firm lacking:

Wistow said in his disability impact statement prepared for the tribunal that the culture was “toxic like nothing I had experienced at the other major City law firms I had worked at before.”  Wistow had previously spent 20 years at Clifford Chance LLP.

Among his claims, Wistow said he was accused of “lacking commitment” when he took a day off to spend time with his sick wife on her birthday, and senior management or HR did not follow up after he told them he was struggling. He also alleged he was “badgered” by the firm’s in-house legal team to leave after returning from bereavement leave.

The firm denies the allegations and says that rather than a discriminatory motivation, Wistow was let go for poor performance and that he was working on a new legal business venture while he was out.

But it’s really what the firm wrote in legal filings in the case that is catching attention:

### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
The law firm “do not doubt the genuineness of his feelings of sadness and grief as a result of this,” Jonathan Cohen, a lawyer for White & Case, said in documents prepared for the hearing. “However, as well-known authority explains, sadness and grief are not disabilities as defined in the Equality Act.”

The firm has also noted they conducted an investigation by external counsel and determined there was no wrongdoing.

Listen, I don’t know nearly enough about any of this (or about British employment law) to opine on the merits of the allegations. But going with grief is not a protected class? Purely as a public relations matter, that’s terrible. While this may be legally accurate, it does pretty much nothing to dispel the perception that White & Case is a “toxic” work environment.

Kathryn Rubino is a Senior Editor at Above the Law, host of [The Jabot podcast](https://open.spotify.com/show/1XC11QhFCWxWr4NQrk2sEA), and co-host of [Thinking Like A Lawyer](https://legaltalknetwork.com/podcasts/thinking-like-a-lawyer/). AtL tipsters are the best, so please connect with her. Feel free to email [her](mailto:kathryn@abovethelaw.com?subject=Your%20Column) with any tips, questions, or comments and follow her on Twitter ([@Kathryn1](//twitter.com/Kathryn1%22)).

# In Shaky Economy, Polsinelli & UnitedLex Team Up To Help Companies Monetize Existing Assets
## Seeking out new revenue streams is the name of the game.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJune 4, 2020 at 3:48 PMJune 4, 2020 at 2:40 PM
4
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/06/in-shaky-economy-polsinelli-unitedlex-team-up-to-help-companies-monetize-existing-assets/&text=In%20Shaky%20Economy,%20Polsinelli%20&%20UnitedLex%20Team%20Up%20To%20Help%20Companies%20Monetize%20Existing%20Assets)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/06/in-shaky-economy-polsinelli-unitedlex-team-up-to-help-companies-monetize-existing-assets/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/06/in-shaky-economy-polsinelli-unitedlex-team-up-to-help-companies-monetize-existing-assets/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
You know that great idea you had that just ended up languishing half-finished in your basement? The one that probably would be worth something if you just took the time out of your already busy schedule to get it done and show it off to the world?

Well, statistically speaking, your idea is probably worthless. But there are big companies out there with some actual expertise who live out the exact same scenario on a higher level. For these companies, it’s all about intellectual property amassed over the years that they never really leveraged or that they used for their own very limited purposes without considering how others could deploy it for their own applications. But with the economy mired in the rough, it might be time to take stock of what’s down in the proverbial basement and see if it has any value.

But that’s easier said than done for these companies, which is where a new joint venture between Polsinelli and UnitedLex comes in. The idea is to take the IP experience of an established law firm and partner it with the technological advantages of a legal services company, with the result being a new approach to IP investment, management, and, where necessary, enforcement capable of bringing new revenue streams to businesses with under-leveraged intellectual property.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
From a press release announcing the venture:

Providing a synergistic approach to patent drafting and prosecution, the partnership of Polsinelli and UnitedLex provides many business-level advantages, including: the ability to handle large patent prosecution projects; a coordinated process that ensures issuance and the strongest possible patent coverage; strategic advice regarding patent filings, including identifying the most impactful markets to pursue; and, the development of a large patent portfolio without a need for extensive in-house resources.

Polsinelli Intellectual Property Department Chair Patrick C. Woolley explained that companies should reconfigure how they think about intellectual property. “IP should be considered a ‘real’ asset with many advantages compared to traditional real assets. Our goal is to enable companies to protect and develop new assets while establishing a new way of leveraging valuable IP assets for years to come.”

Like many of the tech advancements hitting the legal industry these days, it’s unfortunate that it takes a global pandemic to spur changes, but if this leads to a revolution in how companies understand their own assets it should return dividends for years to come.

# Morning Docket: 05.09.19
## * In "dog bites man" news, a majority of young lawyers think being a lawyer sucks. [[Daily Business Review](https://www.law.com/dailybusinessreview/2019/05/08/58-of-young-lawyers-think-legal-profession-is-less-desirable-bar-survey-finds/)] * ICE is now curtailing immigrant access to legal counsel. [[NBC News](https://www.nbcnews.com/news/latino/trump-administration-blocking-immigrants-free-legal-help-attorneys-allege-n1003516)] * Republican Senators call on Attorney General to resign for ignoring congressional subpoenas... oh, wait, that was when Holder did it. [[Tampa Bay Times](https://www.tampabay.com/florida-politics/buzz/2019/05/08/marco-rubio-in-2012-no-one-can-be-above-the-law-not-even-the-attorney-general/)] * The FTC wants a national privacy law and it's absolutely not getting one because that would require a functional government. [[NY Times](https://www.nytimes.com/2019/05/08/business/ftc-hearing-facebook.html)] * R. Kelly paid child support, but he's still trying to keep the whole thing sealed. Don't pee on my leg... actually, you know what, let's just leave it there. [[ABC News](https://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/kelly-hands-62k-child-support-check-legal-troubles/story?id=62918617)] * Stoel Rives elects female managing partner. ### [ How Will Walgreens’ Expansion Into Specialty Pharmacy Affect The Industry? ](https://medcitynews.com/2024/04/walgreens-specialty-pharmacy-drugs/)
Walgreens announced that it is expanding its specialty pharmacy offerings. Experts think that this move could yield several strategic benefits, given the higher profit margins associated with specialty medications compared to traditional drugs. They also think Walgreens’ move could lead to greater competition, consolidation, and innovation within the broader pharmacy industry.

# Sick And Tired Of Biglaw Firm's Glass Ceiling, Associate Quits And Leaves Media Firestorm Over Sexism In Her Wake
## What can you do to combat sexism and gender bias in the legal profession?
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onApril 29, 2016 at 1:27 PM
0
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/04/sick-and-tired-of-biglaw-firms-glass-ceiling-associate-quits-and-leaves-media-firestorm-over-sexism-in-her-wake/&text=Sick%20And%20Tired%20Of%20Biglaw%20Firm’s%20Glass%20Ceiling,%20Associate%20Quits%20And%20Leaves%20Media%20Firestorm%20Over%20Sexism%20In%20Her%20Wake)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/04/sick-and-tired-of-biglaw-firms-glass-ceiling-associate-quits-and-leaves-media-firestorm-over-sexism-in-her-wake/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/04/sick-and-tired-of-biglaw-firms-glass-ceiling-associate-quits-and-leaves-media-firestorm-over-sexism-in-her-wake/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Would you give up your Biglaw life of luxury to escape the glass ceiling at your firm?

Imagine, if you will, the following scenario: You’re a fairly successful associate at a large law firm where you’ve worked for almost a decade. Your annual salary is nearly $400,000, a “very nice salary” by any means. You survived the Great Recession, and you even survived a law firm merger. You think you must surely be under consideration for partnership, but unfortunately, there’s just one problem.

You’re a woman.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
During your time at the firm, you’ve witnessed “blatant gender discrimination, sexual harassment, and a very clear glass ceiling,” and you’re not so sure anymore that this is a lifestyle you want to continue leading. You want to have another child, but you know from experience that “having a baby apparently makes you worth less as a lawyer.”

What do you do?

If you’re completely dissatisfied with your job, you could do exactly what [Kristen Jarvis Johnson](https://www.linkedin.com/in/kristenmj), a nine-year veteran of Squire Patton Boggs, did — you could quit.

The aftermath of Johnson turning in her resignation, however, caused a media firestorm after she engaged in a 10-hour [Ask Me Anything session on Reddit](https://www.reddit.com/r/IAmA/comments/4gi04u/iama_burned_out_international_lawyer_just/). Her story resonated deeply with fellow attorneys. Here’s a brief snippet of what she had to say on the site:

### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
[F]or the past 9 years I have been a Partner-track associate at a Biglaw firm. They sent me to Doha, [Qatar,] for the past 2.5 years. While there, I worked on some amazing projects and was in the most elite of practice groups. … I became disgusted by luxury lifestyle and lawyers who would give anything and everything to make millions. I encountered blatant gender discrimination, sexual harassment, and a very clear glass ceiling. Having a baby apparently makes you worth less as a lawyer. … As a lawyer, I was working sometimes 300 hours in a month and missing my kids all the time. I felt guilty for spending any time not firm related. I never had a vacation where I did not work. I missed my dear grandmother’s funeral in December. In March I made the final decision that this could not last. There must be a better way. So I resigned.

After working for the firm for almost a decade, Johnson began to experience issues with gender bias. In an interview with the [Washington Post](https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/she-ditched-her-400000-a-year-legal-job-after-her-womans-card-only-held-her-back/2016/04/28/a3fb7d4a-0d3a-11e6-a6b6-2e6de3695b0e_story.html), she said a female leader at her firm told her about numerous instances where her ideas and proposals were stolen from her, with male leaders taking credit for them. She’d even heard stories of male partners saying “the partnership isn’t a place for working moms.” But what was the straw that broke the camel’s back and made Johnson decide that she needed to resign?

Here’s a small portion from Johnson’s op-ed piece published in [Big Law Business](https://bol.bna.com/perspective-why-i-quit-big-law-for-a-toy-company/):


Kristin Jarvis Johnson (Photo via LinkedIn)

For my career, I thought I could move past a senior partner trying to grab my leg or asking for a hotel rendezvous during lunch.

Then I hit my breaking point. The working environment spiraled downward after the firm merger. I saw women in leadership positions leave en masse within the first few months of the merger. My workload was constant and unrelenting. I had my second child, and balanced my maternity leave with my continuing work obligations.

Then I was turned down for a bonus for the first time while on maternity leave. I came back to work and hit the ground running in March of last year. Never took a real break, even on vacation, and gave it my all. My new baby was demanding, but I juggled his (and my older son’s) demands with everything else, even taking him and our nanny overseas to continue nursing during a long hearing. My grandmother — after whom my own son is named — died right before a hearing, and her funeral was during another. I was too busy even to mourn, let alone attend the funeral.

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Johnson found diversity lacking at the firm, and felt there was a huge gender imbalance. She was once again turned down for a bonus and told to work harder than she already had been — so she quit. “This is an opportunity to regain the things I value in life, continue to pursue a successful career — but on my own terms, and to stop supporting a broken and biased firm system. I decided not to fight to break a glass ceiling, only to find myself in a hostile, overly-competitive, and unhealthy environment,” Johnson wrote.

Squire Patton Boggs, of course, was “disappointed” by Johnson’s op-ed and “strongly disagree[d]” with her comments, in a statement given to [Big Law Business](https://bol.bna.com/squire-patton-expresses-commitment-to-women-in-response-to-op-ed/):

We are committed to a firm culture that promotes full and equal participation, advancement and retention of women. This vision is supported throughout our firm and guided by the tireless efforts of our Legal Personnel Committee and Women’s Enterprise which were long-ago established to ensure our policies and procedures consider how the sometimes immersive nature of the legal industry could negatively impact women in the profession. This is demonstrated by the many exceptional women leaders throughout our firm, including those serving on our Global Board, acting as Practice Group Leaders and Office Managing Partners, as well as our General Counsel and Global Chief Operating Officer. This commitment extends throughout our Middle East practice. Four lawyers have been promoted to partner in the Middle East since the Squire Patton Boggs merger — two men and two women. Of the women, one was on maternity leave the year she made partner and the second was on maternity leave the year before she made partner. During the period when Ms. Johnson was in Doha, there were four partners in the office, two of whom were women. Our Doha office was also founded in 2003 by a woman partner who was the first non-Qatari attorney licensed to practice law in the State of Qatar and supported Ms. Johnson’s move to the office.

Now that she’s escaped from Biglaw, Johnson wants to “focus [her] energy on doing something great that contributes to breaking down gender barriers and glass ceilings.” She started a company called Boy Story with her sister, and they’re selling life-like dolls for boys — something that’s been missing in toy aisles. If you’re interested in helping her get this idea off the ground, you can donate via her [Kickstarter](https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1632532946/boy-story-finally-cool-boy-action-dolls) page.

What can you do to combat sexism and gender bias in the legal profession? Resigning is one option, but we’re interested in hearing ideas that can be instituted throughout all firms. Please [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=Retention%20of%20Women%20in%20Law%20Firms) or text us (646-820-8477) with your thoughts. All law firms — and Biglaw firms, especially — should be interested in retaining their female talent, instead of driving them out. Leaving shouldn’t be the only option that’s left for women.

[How a ‘Burned-Out’ International Lawyer Ditched Squire Patton Boggs](http://www.americanlawyer.com/home/id=1202756163451?slreturn=20160329113428#sthash.sDx712oH.uxfs) [Am Law Daily]

# The Second Annual Thinking Like A Lawyer Awards Gala
## America's greatest awards show hands out its 2017 trophies.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJanuary 2, 2018 at 3:02 PMJanuary 2, 2018 at 1:58 PM
10
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/01/the-second-annual-thinking-like-a-lawyer-awards-gala/&text=The%20Second%20Annual%20Thinking%20Like%20A%20Lawyer%20Awards%20Gala)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/01/the-second-annual-thinking-like-a-lawyer-awards-gala/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/01/the-second-annual-thinking-like-a-lawyer-awards-gala/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Check out the episode below. And remember to give it some podcast download service love.

# How You Can Turn Your Hobbies Into Networking Gold
## In a profession where differentiation is paramount, your unique pursuits can act as your signature.
By SEJAL PATEL  
onMarch 15, 2024 at 3:43 PMMarch 15, 2024 at 1:20 PM
9
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/03/how-you-can-turn-your-hobbies-into-networking-gold/&text=How%20You%20Can%20Turn%20Your%20Hobbies%20Into%20Networking%20Gold)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/03/how-you-can-turn-your-hobbies-into-networking-gold/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/03/how-you-can-turn-your-hobbies-into-networking-gold/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
In the legal profession, standing out necessitates more than just sharp legal acumen; it calls for an injection of personal creativity and distinctiveness into professional endeavors.

Hobbies and personal interests offer lawyers a unique avenue to deepen industry relationships in a way that is both genuine and enjoyable.

This exploration into merging personal passions with professional networking not only humanizes attorneys but also paves the way for more meaningful connections, setting the stage for networking that enriches both professional and personal lives.

Hobbies — from painting to rock climbing — serve as a reprieve from the demands of the legal world while also acting as a bridge, connecting attorneys on a more personal level with their peers and clients.

Imagine the impact of discovering a shared enthusiasm for mountain biking with a potential client or finding common ground in culinary arts with a colleague.

A Strategy for Genuine Connections

Integrating personal interests into networking doesn’t just add a layer of authenticity to professional interactions; it also opens up new avenues for connection. Here’s how to do it right:

Find Shared Interests: Reflect on your hobbies and consider how they might resonate within your professional circle. Move beyond common clichés and find interests that truly reflect both your personality and those of your contacts.

Create Unique Networking Events: Host events centered around shared hobbies to encourage interaction and camaraderie. Think book clubs, cooking classes, or photography walks — activities that foster genuine connections.

Celebrate Together: Leverage personal and cultural celebrations as networking opportunities. I’ve found hosting events, like a vibrant Diwali celebration, not only honors my heritage but also acts as a dynamic networking event, inviting a mix of friends, clients, and potential connections.

Initiate Conversations About Hobbies: Seamlessly weave your interests into conversations. This approach can reveal shared passions, laying the groundwork for stronger professional relationships.

Focus on Hobbies in Following Up: The true magic in networking often lies in the follow-up, where personal interests can significantly warm up the conversation. Moving from a simple follow-up to an engaging discussion about a shared hobby can transform the dynamic of the interaction, making it more memorable and establishing a rapport that transcends the typical client-lawyer dynamic.

Professionalism Meets Personal Interest

Integrating hobbies into professional networking is an art that requires balancing personal sharing with professional engagement. Here’s how to strike that balance:

Selective Sharing: Gauge the conversation before delving into personal hobbies. Share just enough to pique interest without overwhelming, ensuring your hobbies complement rather than overshadow your professional narrative.

Focus on Universal Appeal: Choose aspects of your hobbies with broader interest. For instance, discussing culinary explorations can engage a wider audience than niche hobbies might.

Integrate With Professionalism: Allow your hobbies to underscore your professional qualities subtly, ensuring that personal interests enhance rather than detract from your professional persona.

Networking Redefined

Redefining networking through personal interests can lead to unforgettable experiences.

For example, inviting clients and colleagues to a Depeche Mode concert, with everyone donning ’80s and ’90s band T-shirts, would break traditional networking barriers and foster connections in an atmosphere of shared enjoyment.

Consider how your hobbies can add depth to your professional interactions. Whether through themed events or casual conversations, let your personal interests guide you to new opportunities and deeper connections.

In a profession where differentiation is paramount, let your unique hobbies act as your signature, creating lasting impressions and enriching your professional network. Your passions not only define you but also open doors to genuine, rewarding connections in the legal landscape.

Sejal Patel is the [Founder of Sage Ivy](https://www.sageivyconsulting.com/about/), a New York-based consultancy specializing in empowering attorneys with innovative practice development strategies. With over 20 years of experience, Sejal applies her expertise in assisting clients convert their relationships into revenue by applying individualized strategies to their networks and leveraging their unique styles authentically.

# The Highest-Ranked Am Law 100 Firm To Slash Salaries Due To COVID-19
## Almost three billion in revenue didn't stop this firm from cutting costs.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onMay 1, 2020 at 7:10 PMMay 1, 2020 at 3:59 PM
6
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/05/the-highest-ranked-am-law-100-firm-to-slash-salaries-due-to-covid-19/&text=The%20Highest-Ranked%20Am%20Law%20100%20Firm%20To%20Slash%20Salaries%20Due%20To%20COVID-19)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/05/the-highest-ranked-am-law-100-firm-to-slash-salaries-due-to-covid-19/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/05/the-highest-ranked-am-law-100-firm-to-slash-salaries-due-to-covid-19/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Ed. note: Welcome to our daily [Trivia Question of the Day](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/trivia-question-of-the-day/) feature.

Which Am Law 100 firm shocked the Biglaw world when it decided to implement austerity measures due to the coronavirus crisis?

Hint: The firm is ranked within the top 5 firms of the 2020 Am Law 100 and is a member of the billion-dollar club.

# Where All The Legal Jobs Are Hiding
## Hiring is slowing down in the legal industry.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onOctober 12, 2022 at 5:17 PMOctober 12, 2022 at 4:26 PM
1

# Law Firm Cancels Shareholder Payments Due To COVID-19
## Everyone is feeling the financial pinch of coronavirus.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onMarch 25, 2020 at 12:43 PMMarch 25, 2020 at 12:28 PM
39
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/03/law-firm-cancels-shareholder-payments-due-to-covid-19/&text=Law%20Firm%20Cancels%20Shareholder%20Payments%20Due%20To%20COVID-19)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/03/law-firm-cancels-shareholder-payments-due-to-covid-19/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/03/law-firm-cancels-shareholder-payments-due-to-covid-19/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Image via Getty)

It looks like[ staff layoffs](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/03/law-firm-layoffs-amid-covid-19/) aren’t the only way law firms are dealing with the financial ramifications of the global pandemic. U.K.-based law firm Gateley, which is a publicly traded entity, announced that they would not be giving its shareholders their interim dividend due to the economic fallout from the coronavirus.

As [reported by](https://www.law.com/2020/03/24/gateley-cancels-shareholder-payouts-in-hedge-against-covid-19-fallout-292-63996/) Law.com, the move is designed to maximize liquidity:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
A dividend of 2.9 pence per share was due to shareholders on March 31. However, in a protective move, the firm announced via the London Stock Exchange on Tuesday that it was now “prudent” to cancel the payout in order to “maximize the group’s short-term liquidity.”

It also said that it would “suspend financial guidance going forward until both the impact and duration of the COVID-19 pandemic becomes clearer.”

Michael Ward, the firm’s CEO, said the firm’s financials are poised to weather the financial turbulence:

“As a board, we consider these measures to be in the best interests of all our stakeholders. Gateley is a resilient and well-balanced business and our economic and geographically diversified business model is well-placed to withstand difficult economic conditions.”

And despite the firm’s stock prices taking a COVID-19 related hit — 20+ percent of the firm’s value was depleted over a two-week period — the financials seem solid. In the firm’s statement on the suspension of dividend payments they also touted their low levels of debt and “a solid first half performance.” This past year saw Gateley’s revenue climb an impressive 19 percent, breaking the 100 million mark — revenue was £102 million — for the first time.

# The Outside Counsel Rankings: The Top Law Firms According To GCs
## The firms you want to call.
By [Brian Dalton](https://abovethelaw.com/author/brian-dalton/)  
onJune 11, 2020 at 1:13 PMJune 11, 2020 at 12:52 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/06/the-outside-counsel-rankings-the-top-law-firms-according-to-gcs/&text=The%20Outside%20Counsel%20Rankings:%20The%20Top%20Law%20Firms%20According%20To%20GCs)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/06/the-outside-counsel-rankings-the-top-law-firms-according-to-gcs/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/06/the-outside-counsel-rankings-the-top-law-firms-according-to-gcs/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
[](https://abovethelaw.com/top-outside-counsel-2020/)In the market for legal services, some opinions simply matter more than others. Arguably, the opinions that matter the most are those of in-house counsel. The premise of our third annual outside counsel rankings is simple and direct. We asked approximately 1,000 in-house counsel two simple questions: 1) “Which law firms does your company engage for legal services?” and 2) “Please indicate the highest level legal work for which your company will engage the particular firm(s).” The “levels” of work were defined along a four-point scale:

1. Cost-efficient, bulk tasks
2. Routine matters
3. High-value, complex matters
4. “Bet-the-company” matters

Earlier this year, those in-house lawyers — from nearly 500 companies and over 40 cities — shared with us their evaluations of their companies’ outside law firms. Check out the results here.

# The Best Brand In Biglaw Isn't Skadden Anymore
## Who's the new top dog in the world of Biglaw?
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onFebruary 14, 2017 at 3:30 PMFebruary 15, 2017 at 11:30 AM
56
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/02/the-best-brand-in-biglaw-isnt-skadden-anymore/&text=The%20Best%20Brand%20In%20Biglaw%20Isn’t%20Skadden%20Anymore)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/02/the-best-brand-in-biglaw-isnt-skadden-anymore/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/02/the-best-brand-in-biglaw-isnt-skadden-anymore/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
The Acritas U.S. Law Firm Brand Index measures the best brand in law with a six-factor test — top of mind awareness, favorability, consideration for top-level deals and litigation, overall usage among U.S.-based clients and inbound usage among international clients — that historically reminds us that Skadden is Coca-Cola and McDonald’s all rolled into one. But this year’s survey threw us a curveball when Skadden fell to number two on the list. Who took over?

Congratulations to Donald Trump’s pet law firm, Jones Day, which took over the top spot in the survey after spending a number of years relegated to the [runner-up slot](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/02/the-best-law-firms-in-america-according-to-in-house-counsel/).

Look, perhaps it’s unfair to attribute Jones Day’s reputation bump to its role as Wormtongue to Trump’s Saruman (it’s a Lord of the Rings joke… [not that Jones Day will get it](https://abovethelaw.com/2014/11/jones-day-does-not-have-a-sense-of-humor/)). After all, there are [two Jones Days](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/02/will-the-real-jones-day-please-stand-up/), and securing this brand promotion required hard work from both Jones Days — including the firm that filed an amicus brief and short-circuited the government’s Ninth Circuit’s argument last week.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
On the other hand, let’s not pretend the firm wasn’t riding Trump to expand its visibility throughout 2016. One would hope that in-house counsel don’t make decisions based on CNN hits, but it’s naïve to think that doesn’t boost the “top of mind awareness” to have senior lawyers providing high-profile opinions every day on cable news.

Jones Day had traditionally scored well in three categories Acritas measures: “Top of mind awareness,” “favorability,” and “top of mind for litigation.” This year, the firm increased in two more components of the survey: “Consideration for major M&A deals” and “inbound use of the firm by international clients.”

I would say Jones Day really stepped up their M&A practice, but as they’re quick to point out, they’ve been [#1 in M&A](http://www.jonesday.com/jones-day-maintains-1-ma-ranking-for-63rd-consecutive-quarter-07-11-2016/) for roughly as long as [UConn’s remained undefeated](http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/02/14/515155652/uconn-women-win-historic-100th-game-in-a-row), so it’s not clear what they did to earn that extra nudge this time.

Congratulations Jones Day, you’ve made yourselves great again!

# Pursuing Justice Podcast Explores Pro Bono In Unprecedented Times
## Over the past year, lawyers have seen firsthand the impact of the pandemic and economic downturn on their pro bono clients. Professionals have come together to share expertise and resources – and Pursuing Justice, a podcast series from Practising Law Institute (PLI), has been telling their stories.
By [Practising Law Institute](https://learning.pli.edu/l/496051/2021-01-28/gmhn7p)

11
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/02/pursuing-justice-podcast-explores-pro-bono-in-unprecedented-times/&text=Pursuing%20Justice%20Podcast%20Explores%20Pro%20Bono%20In%20Unprecedented%20Times)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/02/pursuing-justice-podcast-explores-pro-bono-in-unprecedented-times/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/02/pursuing-justice-podcast-explores-pro-bono-in-unprecedented-times/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
[](https://abovethelaw.com/uploads/2021/02/Pursuing-Justice-logo_ProBono2.jpg)Over the past year, lawyers have seen firsthand the impact of the pandemic and economic downturn on their pro bono clients. For many, the increased need has strengthened their determination to do more. From large firms to smaller regional ones, and from robust nonprofit organizations to smaller community foundations, professionals have come together to share expertise and resources – and [Pursuing Justice, a podcast series from Practising Law Institute (PLI)](http://bit.ly/39Dgb1u), has been telling their stories.

Hosted by [PLI Faculty Fellow Alicia Aiken](http://bit.ly/3rcn9QI), Principal at the Danu Center for Strategic Advocacy and the Director of the Danu Center’s Confidentiality Institute, Pursuing Justice features in-depth discussions with lawyers in private practice, legal services lawyers, and others on topics of interest to the legal community.

A Biglaw Firm Goes All In

As the pandemic unfolded last spring, Aiken spoke with Paul, Weiss Chairman Brad Karp about his firm’s response. Anticipating the impact of the shutdowns on “the most vulnerable in our society,” including workers in hospitality, retail, and food service, as well as the challenges of figuring out the PPP and other relief programs, Karp emailed all of the attorneys at Paul, Weiss, asking who wanted to work on a pro bono project to help individuals and small businesses. Within two hours, he said, over 400 attorneys – around 40 percent of the firm – had signed up, offering to do whatever it took to help gather and communicate essential information.

Listen to the episode, “[Pro Bono in a Pandemic: A Law Firm Goes All In](http://bit.ly/2YB9arm)”


Building Community by Supporting Small Business

As the pandemic progressed, Aiken met with transactional lawyers and nonprofit representatives based in Detroit to learn about pro bono initiatives aimed at helping the community. With small businesses disproportionately suffering losses from the shutdown, Steve Roach, a principal at Miller Canfield, looked for ways to lend his team’s transactional expertise to local businesses. From helping the area’s first women-owned bike shop with microloans and real estate, to advising businesses on employment and corporate governance during the pandemic, Roach and his colleagues take on a variety of matters to strengthen Detroit by supporting small business.

Aiken also spoke with Shamyle Maya Dobbs, CEO of [Michigan Community Resources](https://mi-community.org/), about how the organization has been helping to connect around 400 nonprofit and community-based organizations with legal advice and resources.

Listen to the episode, “[Helping Small Businesses Through Transactional Pro Bono](http://bit.ly/3j6wc2U)”


Pro Bono Begins at Home: A Lawyer Helps Her Community

More recently, Aiken has also turned the tables to be interviewed herself, discussing her long career as a legal services attorney and, more personally, her efforts to boost her own pro bono practice during the pandemic. In Part Two of a conversation, Aiken talks about how she found opportunities to help individuals in her own community, advising on tricky employment issues and more.

Listen to the episode, “[Real Talk About Pro Bono](http://bit.ly/3pFg4b1)”


[](http://bit.ly/3pyb1Jv)Practising Law Institute is a nonprofit learning organization dedicated to keeping attorneys and other professionals at the forefront of knowledge and expertise. PLI is chartered by the Regents of the University of the State of New York and was founded in 1933 by Harold P. Seligson. The organization provides the highest quality, accredited, continuing legal and professional education programs in a variety of formats which are delivered by more than 4,000 volunteer faculty including prominent lawyers, judges, investment bankers, accountants, corporate counsel, and U.S. and international government regulators. PLI publishes a comprehensive library of Treatises, Course Handbooks, Answer Books and Journals also available through the PLI PLUS online platform. The essence of PLI’s mission is its commitment to the pro bono community. View PLI’s upcoming live webcasts [here](http://bit.ly/3pyb1Jv).

# Seyfarth Says Yes To Defense Of Anti-Gay Bias Case
## Will Seyfarth come to regret taking on this case?
By [David Lat](https://abovethelaw.com/author/david-lat/)  
onAugust 23, 2013 at 3:43 PMAugust 25, 2013 at 10:05 AM
16
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2013/08/seyfarth-says-yes-to-defense-of-anti-gay-bias-case/&text=Seyfarth%20Says%20Yes%20To%20Defense%20Of%20Anti-Gay%20Bias%20Case)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2013/08/seyfarth-says-yes-to-defense-of-anti-gay-bias-case/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2013/08/seyfarth-says-yes-to-defense-of-anti-gay-bias-case/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
[E]ven the most disgusting criminals should have access to counsel when they violate the law, and Exxon’s shareholders will now pay big bucks for Seyfarth’s lawyers, who are probably some of the most expensive corporate defense lawyers in the country. But I don’t think there’s any need for Seyfarth to run up their billable hours since Freedom to Work would like to settle the case today.

— [Tico Almeida](http://www.freedomtowork.org/?page_id=18), founder and president of [Freedom to Work](http://www.freedomtowork.org/), commenting on [Seyfarth Shaw’s decision](http://www.washingtonblade.com/2013/08/23/seyfarth-shaw/) to defend a case alleging anti-gay bias at Exxon Mobil — one of the few Fortune 500 companies that lacks a written nondiscrimination policy prohibiting discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation.

(Will Seyfarth come to regret this case? Let’s discuss….)

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  

Here’s more about the matter from the [Washington Blade](http://www.washingtonblade.com/2013/08/23/seyfarth-shaw/):

Seyfarth Shaw is representing oil-and-gas giant Exxon Mobil against charges of alleged anti-gay bias in hiring practices, according to the LGBT group Freedom to Work.

Tico Almeida, president of Freedom to Work, told the Washington Blade on Thursday night the Chicago office of Seyfarth Shaw elected this month to represent Exxon Mobil in the lawsuit, which was filed by his organization and is pending before the Illinois Department of Human Rights….

Freedom to Work [filed the lawsuit against Exxon Mobil in May](http://www.washingtonblade.com/2013/05/22/exxon-mobil-faces-lawsuit-over-alleged-anti-gay-bias/) after conducting a test in which it sent two fictitious resumes for a job opening at the company in Illinois. One was from a more qualified applicant who outed herself as LGBT on her resume; the other was a less qualified applicant who gave no indications about her sexual orientation or gender identity. The less qualified non-LGBT applicant received multiple callbacks, the more qualified LGBT applicant received nothing.

Regarding his reference to settling the case, Almeida isn’t interested in monetary recovery. He’d be happy with Exxon Mobil adopting a policy prohibiting discrimination against LGBT employees:

### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
“In fact, one settlement option would be for Exxon to copy and paste Seyfarth’s own LGBT workplace policies, which have previously earned the lawfirm a 100 percent LGBT rating from the HRC,” Almeida said. “Exxon could also copy and paste the Chevron LGBT workplace policy, and we would accept that as part of the settlement.”

Alas, gasoline going back to $3 a gallon is probably more likely to happen than Exxon adopting such a policy, at least willingly. From a piece that James Stewart wrote for the [New York Times](http://www.nytimes.com/2013/05/25/business/a-corporate-giants-missing-support-for-gay-rights.html?pagewanted=all):

[A]s social attitudes and other corporations’ policies on the subject of gay rights have changed drastically, Exxon Mobil has moved steadily further from the mainstream, even within the energy sector. According to the Human Rights Campaign, 88 percent of Fortune 500 companies have adopted written nondiscrimination policies prohibiting harassment and discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation, as have all the major integrated oil companies that compete with Exxon Mobil.

As Stewart observed, Exxon’s policy (or lack thereof) “seems to be hurting the company with gay and lesbian customers and employees.” Could handling this controversial case hurt Seyfarth similarly?

As we noted [last year](https://abovethelaw.com/2012/11/the-best-law-firms-for-lgbt-lawyers/), Seyfarth enjoys a 100 percent rating on the Human Rights Campaign’s Corporate Equality Index, which measures employers on their commitment to LGBT equality. Could this case put Seyfarth’s perfect score in jeopardy? Quite possibly, according to the [Blade](http://www.washingtonblade.com/2013/08/23/seyfarth-shaw/):

### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Michael Cole-Schwartz, a Human Rights Campaign spokesperson, said his organization would dock a hypothetical law firm for representing Exxon Mobil in a case alleging anti-gay bias at the company.

“Yes, we would and have done so in the past,” Cole-Schwartz said. “The firm Foley & Lardner was docked 15 points previously for their work representing organizations trying to stop marriage equality (engagements which have since ended and they are no longer docked), although it should be noted the firm has also had a long history of pro bono support for LGBT causes.”

After Foley partner Cleta Mitchell, whom I once dubbed [“an anti-gay gay icon,”](https://abovethelaw.com/2013/04/cleta-mitchell-of-foley-lardner-an-anti-gay-gay-icon/) stopped representing the National Organization for Marriage (NOM), the firm’s Corporate Equality Index score [skyrocketed](https://abovethelaw.com/2012/11/the-best-law-firms-for-lgbt-lawyers/).

UPDATE (8/25/2013, 10 a.m.): A commenter offers this clarification about Cleta Mitchell:

You got the Foley & Lardner story a little wrong. Cleta Mitchell did not quit working for NOM. Because of the controversy that arose from her representation of NOM, Foley devised a policy that any attorney that takes on work either for or against gay marriage may not invoke Foley’s name as a firm, but may still take on such work in their personal name. Foley didn’t force Mitchell to quit representing NOM — it merely won’t let attorneys represent either side of the gay marriage issue using the firm’s name.

Foley isn’t the only Biglaw firm that has ended a controversial client relationship under pressure from the LGBT community. Recall that King & Spalding famously [dropped its DOMA defense](https://abovethelaw.com/2011/04/paul-clement-quits-king-spalding-after-ks-moves-to-drop-doma-defense/), even though that move led former Solicitor General Paul Clement to leave K&S for the [Bancroft boutique](http://www.bancroftpllc.com/professionals/paul-d-clement/).

Speaking of Bancroft, that’s the kind of firm that would be better situated to defend a case like Freedom to Work’s. As Tico Almeida notes, Exxon Mobil is entitled to representation, but it might be better off with a boutique instead of Biglaw. The quality of lawyering would be just as high, but the risk of unpleasant entanglement would be lower.

Large firms like Seyfarth are arguably too big to handle such controversial cases comfortably; they have too many current and prospective employees and clients who might be upset by their defense of alleged anti-gay bias. In contrast, elite conservative boutiques like Bancroft or [Cooper & Kirk](http://cooperkirk.com/), which defended California’s Proposition 8 ban on gay marriage, don’t have such worries. They are small firms, with fewer clients and employees, and many of those clients and workers are social conservatives, who would be unfazed by defending a large corporation accused of anti-gay prejudice.

As word gets out about its involvement in the case, will Seyfarth Shaw stand stalwart in its defense of Exxon Mobil? Stay tuned.

[Chicago firm to defend Exxon Mobil against charges of anti-gay bias](http://www.washingtonblade.com/2013/08/23/seyfarth-shaw/) [Washington Blade]
[Exxon Defies Calls to Add Gays to Anti-Bias Policy](http://www.nytimes.com/2013/05/25/business/a-corporate-giants-missing-support-for-gay-rights.html?pagewanted=all) [New York Times]
[Shareholders of Exxon Mobil Reject Gay Discrimination Ban](http://www.nytimes.com/2013/05/30/business/exxon-shareholders-reject-gay-discrimination-ban.html) [Associated Press]

# Donald Trump Has The Kind Of Lawyers You Get When You Offer To Pay Your Attorneys In Livestock, If At All
## World's worst client
By [Liz Dye](https://abovethelaw.com/author/edye/)  
onSeptember 7, 2022 at 3:45 PMSeptember 7, 2022 at 3:12 PM
54
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/09/donald-trump-has-the-kind-of-lawyers-you-get-when-you-offer-to-pay-your-attorneys-in-livestock-if-at-all/&text=Donald%20Trump%20Has%20The%20Kind%20Of%20Lawyers%20You%20Get%20When%20You%20Offer%20To%20Pay%20Your%20Attorneys%20In%20Livestock,%20If%20At%20All)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/09/donald-trump-has-the-kind-of-lawyers-you-get-when-you-offer-to-pay-your-attorneys-in-livestock-if-at-all/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/09/donald-trump-has-the-kind-of-lawyers-you-get-when-you-offer-to-pay-your-attorneys-in-livestock-if-at-all/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Photo by Isaac Brekken/Getty)

Donald Trump tried to pay his lawyer with a horse. That’s it, that’s the tweet.

[The Guardian](https://www.theguardian.com/books/2022/sep/05/donald-trump-tried-pay-lawyer-horse-book-david-enrich-servants-of-the-damned) got its hands on an advance copy of “Servants of the Damned: Giant Law Firms, Donald Trump and the Corruption of Justice,” by New York Times reporter David Enrich, which contains a hilarious anecdote of the [famously tightfisted client](https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2020/08/trump-files-time-trumps-lawyers-sued-trump/) trying to settle accounts by giving his lawyer the deed to a race horse.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Describing “a lawyer at a white-shoe firm” who worked for Trump in the 1990s, Enrich writes: “The bill came to about $2m and Trump refused to pay.

“After a while, the lawyer lost patience, and he showed up, unannounced, at Trump Tower. Someone sent him up to Trump’s office. Trump was initially pleased to see him – he didn’t betray any sense of sheepishness – but the lawyer was steaming.

“‘I’m incredibly disappointed,’ he scolded Trump. ‘There’s no reason you haven’t paid us.’

“Trump made some apologetic noises. Then he said: ‘I’m not going to pay your bill. I’m going to give you something more valuable.’ What on earth is he talking about? the lawyer wondered. ‘I have a stallion,’ Trump continued. ‘It’s worth $5m.’ Trump rummaged around in a filing cabinet and pulled out what he said was a deed to a horse. He handed it to the lawyer.”

Enrich describes the lawyer’s stunned and angry response, in which he threatened to sue.

Trump, Enrich writes, “eventually coughed up at least a portion of what he owed”.

As it is written, so shall it be.

Even now that Trump has infinity GriftBux through the Republican National Committee and various PACs to pay his attorneys, sometimes he still stiffs his lawyers just for the hell of it. As in the case of Rudy Giuliani, whom Trump refused to pay more or less on principal. The Guardian outlines another telling episode from an upcoming book on America’s Erstwhile Mayor, [Giuliani: The Rise and Tragic Fall of America’s Mayor](https://www.theguardian.com/books/2022/aug/24/donald-trump-secret-mar-a-lago-stay-rudy-giuliani-drink-depression-wife-andrew-kirtzman-book), by author Andrew Kirtzman.

Kirtzman writes that Giuliani’s girlfriend/assistant Maria Ryan wrote a letter to Trump in January of 2021 requesting $2.5 million for “defending you during the Russia hoax investigation and then the impeachment,” a “general pardon,” and the Presidential Medal of Freedom. None of the above was forthcoming, with Trump saying that Giuliani would get “paid on the come,” a casino reference to craps indicating that the lawyer was SOL unless he managed somehow to keep Trump in office for a second term.

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)

# This Biglaw Firm Is Out Of Touch With Associate Compensation Issues
## And don't let the door hit you on the ass on the way out!
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onAugust 2, 2016 at 1:33 PMAugust 7, 2016 at 3:49 PM
3
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/08/this-biglaw-firm-is-out-of-touch-with-associate-compensation-issues/&text=This%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Is%20Out%20Of%20Touch%20With%20Associate%20Compensation%20Issues)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/08/this-biglaw-firm-is-out-of-touch-with-associate-compensation-issues/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/08/this-biglaw-firm-is-out-of-touch-with-associate-compensation-issues/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
This summer will go down in associate lore as the summer of MoneyLaw, when the market leaders, followers, and also-rans made themselves known.

Given the intense attention that compensation has gotten from associates around the country, and with recruiting season just around the corner, if you were the Global Head of Legal Personnel and part of your firm’s Senior Management Team, you’d probably be used to answering, or at least artfully dodging, questions about associate compensation.

If your firm had been [criticized for ponying up the headline-grabbing money](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/biglaw-firm-does-right-by-junior-associates-mid-levels-and-senior-associates-not-so-much/) for junior associates, while leaving midlevel and senior associates with a [poorly explained salary range](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/07/biglaw-firm-finally-reveals-compensation-for-midlevel-and-senior-associates-and-they-are-pissed/), you’d probably be used to questions about compensation. Especially when many insiders believe the firm’s new salary policy will lead to compression (i.e., [paying first-year associates market salary](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/no-you-are-not-matching-the-market-1st-years-to-180k-doesnt-tell-the-whole-story/) but giving more senior associates less money than the prevailing market amount so that the firm still has a dubious claim of paying “market rate”). If that was the job you had, and the questions you’ve probably heard multiple times since Cravath unveiled the new market standard for compensation two months ago, you’d probably have a really great answer for senior associates when they complained about their salary.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Reed Smith is just such a firm. And Global Head of Legal Personnel [Casey Ryan](https://www.reedsmith.com/casey_ryan/), in an associate meeting meant to discuss compensation issues, had a very clear message for lawyers who were upset that they’d likely see less money than their peers at rival firms:

If someone doesn’t think they are being paid fairly on the market, they can leave.

And don’t let the door hit you on the ass on the way out!

UPDATE (8/3/16, 2:13 p.m.): The quote above from Ryan is produced just as it was relayed to Above the Law by our network of tipsters. However, a representative of the firm has reached out to provide some additional context for how Ryan presented her comments:

By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onDecember 10, 2020 at 5:47 PMDecember 10, 2020 at 3:19 PM

# In-House Counsel: Tell Us About Your Outside Law Firms
## Which law firms do you call on most as in-house counsel?
By ABOVE THE LAW  
onDecember 14, 2023 at 12:18 PMDecember 14, 2023 at 11:35 AM
6
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/12/corporate-counsel-law-firm-survey/&text=In-House%20Counsel:%20Tell%20Us%20About%20Your%20Outside%20Law%20Firms)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/12/corporate-counsel-law-firm-survey/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/12/corporate-counsel-law-firm-survey/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Every year, we compile a list of the [top law firms](https://abovethelaw.com/top-outside-counsel-rankings-2023/) in the country, and it’s time to start gathering data for 2024.

As always, to build our Outside Counsel Rankings, we turn to those whose perspectives matter most to law firms — the clients who hire them.

We invite all in-house attorneys to tell us about the firms you work with. Whom do you hire most often for routine matters? Which firms do you call when the stakes are highest?

### [ How Will Walgreens’ Expansion Into Specialty Pharmacy Affect The Industry? ](https://medcitynews.com/2024/04/walgreens-specialty-pharmacy-drugs/)

# Biglaw Gaslighting 101: Blaming Layoffs On Associate Salaries
## Blaming employees for making too much money is always poor form but in Biglaw it's also complete nonsense.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJune 22, 2023 at 10:28 AMJune 22, 2023 at 9:08 AM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/biglaw-gaslighting-101-blaming-layoffs-on-associate-salaries/&text=Biglaw%20Gaslighting%20101:%20Blaming%20Layoffs%20On%20Associate%20Salaries)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/biglaw-gaslighting-101-blaming-layoffs-on-associate-salaries/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/biglaw-gaslighting-101-blaming-layoffs-on-associate-salaries/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Whenever Biglaw executes a round of associate salary raises, some partner at some firm — almost always an Am Law second 50 if not second 100 shop — will declare that it will all end in tears when firms have to lay off these high-priced associates the next year. And whenever there’s an economic speedbump, someone is going to proclaim that Biglaw would’ve gotten away with it without laying anyone off if it weren’t for you pesky kids earning higher salaries. It’s a finely tuned narrative machine. Honestly, it’s not even clear that these partners do it on purpose… it’s like they’re psychically compelled to spread this message.

Yesterday, the American Lawyer [featured the latest in this time-honored tradition](https://www.law.com/2023/06/20/layoffs-are-spreading-after-all-theres-only-so-much-work-to-go-around/):

Meanwhile, other law firm leaders in the Am Law 100 are confident that their more measured hiring and compensation practices will be enough to stave off layoffs at their own firms.

“You’ve got a lot of firms out there that from an image perspective believe they have to match the Cravath scale or at least get very close but they don’t generate the profit margins that those firms do,” said Cozen O’Connor CEO Michael Heller. “By overpaying their associates, they have to literally just lay those associates off.”

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
In a word, balderdash.

On its face, the statement contends that the layoffs we’re seeing stem from firms paying market and cutting profit margins to the bone. Except… that’s not really indicative of the firms laying people off.

Orrick is delivering [north of $3M in PEP with RPL over $1M](https://www.law.com/law-firm-profile/?id=227&name=Orrick). Same for [Cooley](https://www.law.com/law-firm-profile/?id=65&name=Cooley) and [Fenwick & West](https://www.law.com/law-firm-profile/?id=102&name=Fenwick-West). Gunderson doesn’t report that data to Am Law, but it’s hard to believe it’s fallen into pauperism. Stepping away from the tech-heavy layoffs, both [Goodwin](https://www.law.com/law-firm-profile/?id=123&name=Goodwin-Procter) and [Dechert](https://www.law.com/law-firm-profile/?id=81&name=Dechert-LLP) meet the $3M+/$1M+ threshold. Hell, Goodwin chased its layoffs by immediately [turning around and hiring more high compensation lawyers](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/01/sure-goodwin-just-laid-off-a-bunch-of-lawyers-but-that-doesnt-mean-theyre-going-to-stop-adding-laterals/) putting the lie to the idea that its layoffs are salary related. Of the high profile layoffs, only Reed Smith misses these financial numbers with [PEP at $1.6M and its RPL just a hair under $1M](https://www.law.com/law-firm-profile/?id=250&name=Reed-Smith). So maybe those layoffs involve a little profit taking… though they aren’t fully matched with the Cravath scale anyway!

If the general rule for compensation is to pay attorneys roughly a third of what they bring in, then without knowing the distribution across class years, the Cravath scale would back of the napkin fit for all these firms. The average associate is making around $300K and producing about $1M. Perfecto.

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)

### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
So how do we always end up with this fantasy that rising associate compensation drives firm layoffs? And why does it always arrive like clockwork after a couple force reductions?

It’s posturing — both vertical and horizontal.

Cozen, at [$1.1M PEP and an RPL of $850K](https://www.law.com/law-firm-profile/?id=1728&name=Cozen-O%27Connor), pays a step below market. The firm has to sell its [sometimes unhappy](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/cozen-raise-2021/) associates on the prospect that the grass is greener on this side of the fence. Layoffs afford an easy opportunity to spin lower compensation as doing the lawyers a favor. “Our fiscal conservatism may annoy you in the boom times but we don’t have to lay you off like some firms,” is a compelling if not entirely accurate message. That’s the vertical posturing.

Horizontally, firms competing for talent without the benefit of matching compensation always fear another round of hikes putting them even further behind their peers. When the conventional wisdom is that “raises beget layoffs,” it’s a passive signal to peer firms (and not-so-peer firms) to hold the line. Orrick isn’t struggling to pay Cravath salaries… but Cozen might struggle to compete when Orrick joins Cravath on another salary war adventure.

Again, I honestly don’t think these folks realize what they’re doing. It’s just an article of faith to some partners out there regardless of market reality.

###Sponsored

If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
So, no Virginia, there is no such thing as a salary induced layoff. There are firms unwilling to pay associates in practice groups that aren’t currently busy. Maybe they’re right to save that expense, maybe they’re just compromising future success when those areas roar back and they’ve jettisoned needed capacity. But that’s what’s going on. Not a bevy of elite law firms scraping by with razor thin profit margins because of a bunch of greedy associates.

[Layoffs Are Spreading. After All, There’s Only So Much Work to Go Around](https://www.law.com/2023/06/20/layoffs-are-spreading-after-all-theres-only-so-much-work-to-go-around/) [American Lawyer]

[Joe Patrice](http://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/) is a senior editor at Above the Law and co-host of [Thinking Like A Lawyer](http://legaltalknetwork.com/podcasts/thinking-like-a-lawyer/). Feel free to [email](mailto:joepatrice@abovethelaw.com) any tips, questions, or comments. Follow him on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/josephpatrice) if you’re interested in law, politics, and a healthy dose of college sports news. Joe also serves as a [Managing Director at RPN Executive Search](https://www.rpnexecsearch.com/josephpatrice).

# Is Biglaw Using Early Partnership To Keep Valuable Associates From Jumping Ship?
## Worried about associates leaving? Make 'em partner NOW.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onJune 9, 2021 at 3:11 PMJune 9, 2021 at 4:19 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/cahill-partners/&text=Is%20Biglaw%20Using%20Early%20Partnership%20To%20Keep%20Valuable%20Associates%20From%20Jumping%20Ship?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/cahill-partners/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/cahill-partners/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
One of the unexpected reverberations from our pandemic year+ is just how well Biglaw fared. The top of the pack made quite the pretty penny, with a booming corporate market. That means that the [lateral attorney market](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/the-biglaw-lateral-market-is-fire-right-now/) has seen a ton of [action](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/no-t14-degree-no-peer-firm-work-no-problem-biglaw-firms-change-hiring-criteria-in-white-hot-market/), forcing Biglaw firms that want to [hold onto their talent](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/05/special-bonuses-are-just-another-way-to-keep-associates-hooked-on-biglaw/) to roll out the red carpet. So, suddenly remote-only work is an option (at least for the truly coveted) and those generous mid-year [special bonuses sweeping](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/will-all-of-this-bonus-money-be-enough-to-keep-associates-from-making-lateral-moves/) through Biglaw are looking like golden handcuffs meant to keep associates at their firms.

But the lateral market is savvy, countering with [staggering](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/kirkland-uses-its-immense-wealth-in-pursuit-of-associates/) — we’ve heard tales of six figures — [signing bonuses](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/05/lateral-associates-are-taking-home-gigantic-signing-bonuses-in-this-hot-job-market/) for associates. So what’s a firm anxious to keep their associates to do? Perhaps an unexpected partnership election is in order.

Cahill, Gordon & Reindel is one of the smaller Biglaw firms — at least by headcount, and their partnership classes are usually no more than a handful of folks. And, like a lot of Biglaw firms, the partnership elections come in the beginning of the year — we’re talking [early February](https://www.cahill.com/news/firm-news/2021-02-09-cahill-announces-new-partner-elections) or in [January, ](https://www.cahill.com/news/firm-news/2020-01-14-cahill-announces-new-partner-and-counsel-elections)generally [speaking](https://www.cahill.com/news/firm-news/2019-01-16-cahill-announces-election-of-new-partners). So, imagine everyone’s surprise when [the firm announced ](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/cahill-partners/2/)its second round of partner elections in 2021, these effective July 1, 2021.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
And those elevated to partner in this unusual move are [C. Anthony Wolfe](https://www.cahill.com/professionals/anthony-wolfe) and [Elizabeth Yahl](https://www.cahill.com/professionals/elizabeth-yahl). Two associates that just happen to work in the super hot capital markets practice area. Hmmm, this sure feels like a bid to keep valuable attorneys at the firm rather than risk losing them to the lateral market by waiting until 2022 to elect them to the partnership.

We reached out to the firm about the… noteworthy timing but have yet to hear back.

Congratulations to those elevated.
