# Cravath Names New Partners -- And All Three Are Women
## This elite firm's announcement shows there's no trade-off between equality and excellence.
By [David Lat](https://abovethelaw.com/author/david-lat/)  
onNovember 16, 2016 at 7:14 PMNovember 18, 2016 at 8:49 AM
97
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/11/cravath-names-new-partners-and-all-three-are-women/&text=Cravath%20Names%20New%20Partners%20—%20And%20All%20Three%20Are%20Women)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/11/cravath-names-new-partners-and-all-three-are-women/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/11/cravath-names-new-partners-and-all-three-are-women/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Worldwide Plaza, where the magic happens — or, at least, where Biglaw compensation levels are set.

Biglaw has big problems when it comes to gender equality. While [juicy](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/traci-ribeiro/) [lawsuits](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/kerrie-campbell/) generate [headlines](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/01/biglaw-partner-alleges-sexism-derailed-her-career-in-a-new-lawsuit/?rf=1), one need not rely on those cases — which at this point involve just allegations, after all — to make the diagnosis. Focus instead on the fundamentals — like the fact that women represent just [18 percent of equity partners](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/09/tracking-10-years-of-womens-progress-in-the-legal-profession/) in large law firms.

One possible response: that statistic covers partners at all levels of seniority, so there’s a lag time here, and the problem will naturally go away as the years pass. If women make up about 50 percent of law school students, they’ll eventually make up 50 percent of equity partners, right?

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Alas, that might be a bit optimistic, at least if firms don’t make an effort to improve the retention and promotion of women lawyers. As reflected in recent partner promotion announcements, this remains a live issue. For example, just last week Cleary Gottlieb named [eight new partners](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/11/cleary-gottliebs-new-partner-class-where-are-the-women/2/), and only [one was a woman](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/11/cleary-gottliebs-new-partner-class-where-are-the-women/). Commenting to Above the Law, managing partner [Mark Leddy](https://www.clearygottlieb.com/professionals/mark-leddy) said, “There are no excuses; we must do better. We have undertaken a number of initiatives and are firmly committed to making the investments necessary to ensure that our culture is one in which all lawyers can thrive.”

Now, one shouldn’t put too much stock in any one firm’s new partner class. It’s more important to look at the big picture, which does seem to be improving. According to a [new report](http://dfalliance.com/research/new-partner-report/) by the Diversity & Flexibility Alliance, of those lawyers promoted to partnership at 134 large U.S. law firms over the last year, [37 percent are women](http://www.law360.com/corporate/articles/859294/number-of-female-partners-in-biglaw-hits-5-year-high?nl_pk=be0f8226-d5ba-43b9-bffa-9431e90fddc5&utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=corporate).

Thirty-seven percent, well above the overall representation of women in Biglaw partnership, is nice. But you know what’s even nicer? One hundred percent. From a tipster:

Partner election night at Cravath: Mungovan, Leraris, D’Amico. All women.

From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Yes, that’s right. Say hello to the three new partners at the firm that once again took the #1 spot in our [ATL Power 100 Law Firm Rankings](https://abovethelaw.com/careers/2017-power-100-law-firm-rankings/), a place you might have heard of — Cravath, Swaine & Moore:

- Margaret D’Amico: An antitrust litigator, D’Amico joined Cravath in 2008, after finishing law school at Harvard (where she also obtained her undergraduate degree).
- Rory Leraris: Also a litigator (but focused on general commercial matters), Leraris arrived at Cravath in 2008, after graduating from the University of Chicago Law School. She earned her undergraduate degree from Amherst.
- Kara Mungovan: Like D’Amico, Mungovan is a graduate of Harvard College and Harvard Law School. She is a tax lawyer.

Margaret D’Amico

Two litigators, one tax lawyer, and six degrees from top-flight schools. The trio will join the partnership on January 1, 2017.

What’s especially noteworthy (and heartening) about this news is that the Cravath partnership is one of the most meritocratic in Biglaw. It’s a small partnership, with fewer than 100 members, and when picking partners, the firm emphasizes excellence in lawyering above all else. Unlike most firms, Cravath doesn’t pay much attention to the vicissitudes of the economic cycle or the trendiness or power of particular practice groups (which makes the absence of general corporate lawyers from this list less surprising). The Cravath partnership process is also less political than at many other places (although it’s impossible to remove politics entirely from partnership decisions).

In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  

Rory A. Leraris

This is not the first good news on gender equity to come out of Cravath this year. In July, the firm announced that M&A maven Faiza Saeed will [take over from Allen Parker as presiding partner](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/07/cravath-elects-its-next-presiding-partner-ma-star-faiza-saeed/) next year. As we noted at the time, “it’s fair to say that as of January, Cravath will be the most prestigious, profitable, and white-shoe firm to boast a woman leader.”

Congratulations to these three outstanding lawyers on joining one of the most exclusive clubs in the legal profession — and congratulations and thanks to Cravath for setting an excellent example for its fellow firms. May they follow Cravath’s lead on gender equality as surely as they do on [base salaries](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/breaking-ny-to-180k-cravath-raises-associate-base-salaries/) and [bonuses](https://abovethelaw.com/2015/12/associate-bonus-watch-cravath-announces-its-2015-associate-bonuses/).


Kara L. Mungovan

Has your firm recently announced its new partners? If so, what do the selections — in terms of number, practice areas, diversity, or other considerations — say about the state of your firm? Feel free to [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20New%20Partners) (subject line “[Firm Name] New Partners”) or text us (646-820-8477). Thanks.

# Biglaw Firm Cuts Retirement Matching In Effort To Avoid Layoffs
## Suspending the 401(k) matching program won't even be enough to cover the firm's losses.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onMarch 31, 2020 at 10:46 AMMarch 31, 2020 at 10:39 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/03/biglaw-firm-cuts-retirement-matching-in-effort-to-avoid-layoffs/&text=Biglaw%20Firm%20Cuts%20Retirement%20Matching%20In%20Effort%20To%20Avoid%20Layoffs)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/03/biglaw-firm-cuts-retirement-matching-in-effort-to-avoid-layoffs/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/03/biglaw-firm-cuts-retirement-matching-in-effort-to-avoid-layoffs/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Image via Getty)

It’s only Tuesday and it’s already been a really long week for the legal profession. Thus far, we’ve seen associate [layoffs and salary cuts](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/03/am-law-100-firm-announces-associate-layoffs-and-other-cost-cutting-measures/), partners [slowing their cash distributions](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/03/biglaw-firm-cuts-back-partner-compensation-amid-covid-19-economic-upheaval/), and firms [pausing lateral hiring](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/03/biglaw-firms-put-lateral-hiring-on-pause-due-to-coronavirus-crisis/), all because of the coronavirus crisis. Some Biglaw firms are now scrambling to do all they can to avoid cutting personnel during a health crisis.

Marshall Dennehey, an Am Law 200 firm, has announced that effective May 1, it is suspending a 4 percent employer 401(k) match until next year. The firm’s matching program has an 80 percent participation rate among its 1,200 employees, but president and CEO Mark Thompson wouldn’t disclose how much money this financial maneuver would save — just that it wouldn’t be enough.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
The [Legal Intelligencer](https://www.law.com/thelegalintelligencer/2020/03/30/in-an-effort-to-avoid-layoffs-marshall-dennehey-halts-retirement-matching/) has more on what’s going on at Marshall Dennehey:

“We’re trying to offset these losses and live up to our family values and keep everybody together. This was a measure we could take as an alternative to layoffs and pay cuts,” [Thompson] said. …

Thompson and firm leadership have deep reservations about cutting head count or salaries. While suspending 401(k) matching will not fully cover the revenue the firm anticipates it will lose, Thompson said he does not anticipate firm layoffs. He said he prides the firm on having a family environment, and he loathes the idea of a laid-off employee losing their health insurance in midst of a public health crisis.

The response from employees, Thompson said, has been overwhelmingly positive in light of the cuts that have already been announced across the industry.

“We have received expressions of gratitude,” Thompson said. “People are scared and we’re trying to give them one less thing to worry about.” He expects the matching program will return to the firm in 2021.

Let’s hope Marshall Dennehey’s plan comes to fruition and the firm can save jobs.

# Standing Against Pandemic Profiteers
## International white-shoe firms continue to push corporations toward claims that threaten to undermine the public good.
By Mandeep S. Minhas  
onSeptember 11, 2020 at 5:17 PMFebruary 19, 2023 at 9:41 AM
24
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/standing-against-pandemic-profiteers/&text=Standing%20Against%20Pandemic%20Profiteers)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/standing-against-pandemic-profiteers/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/standing-against-pandemic-profiteers/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
During a 1997 investor-state dispute, a Canadian attorney noted that “it wouldn’t matter if a substance was liquid plutonium destined for a child’s breakfast cereal. If the government bans a product and a U.S.-based company loses profit, the company can claim damages under NAFTA.” The corporate lawyer’s statement summarizes the power of Investment State Dispute Settlement (ISDS) systems, which allow corporations to sue governments in secretive ad hoc tribunals. How depressing that international white-shoe firms continue to push corporations toward claims that threaten to undermine the public good. With the help of their lawyers, corporations are preparing to shake down governments around the world for adopting regulatory measures addressing the health and economic effects of the COVID-19 pandemic.

For decades, economists and human rights advocates have argued against the inclusion of ISDS clauses in free-trade deals. The tribunals allow foreign companies to extract dubious lost or expected profits from governments that have promulgated regulations involving water access, land rights, and labor disputes. The governments cannot exert their own claims to fight violations by corporations because the tribunals create one-way rights. Moreover, the ISDS system has often exposed weaker economies to the greed of investors involved in third-party litigation funding. No wonder that a [former European Union trade commissioner](https://www.politico.eu/article/isds-the-most-toxic-acronym-in-europe/) once declared ISDS as the “most toxic acronym in Europe.”

The efforts to reform investor-state legal mechanisms are too slow. As the Columbia Center on Sustainable Investment (CCSI) [argued](http://ccsi.columbia.edu/2020/05/05/isds-moratorium-during-covid-19/) in May, we need an immediate moratorium on all ISDS claims during the COVID-19 pandemic and its aftermath. As autumn approaches, there is no doubt that governments need to continue directing their capital and legal resources to the public health emergency. Law firms, however, have ignored the alarm from the CCSI and [650 other civil society groups](http://s2bnetwork.org/sign-the-pen-letter-to-governments-on-isds-and-covid-19/). For example, Ropes & Gray has been working on [pro bono](https://www.ropesgray.com/en/newsroom/news/2020/08/Project-Citizenship-and-Ropes-Gray-Ask-Federal-Court-to-Rescind-Illegal-Rule) COVID-19 matters while [alerting](https://www.ropesgray.com/en/newsroom/alerts/2020/04/COVID-19-Measures-Leveraging-Investment-Agreements-to-Protect-Foreign-Investments) paying clients to consider actions under investment treaties. As Anand Giridharadas, who critiques the way elites treat philanthropy, [has said](https://www.vox.com/recode/2019/5/22/18634612/anand-giridharadas-billionaires-philanthropy-zuckerberg-bezos-kara-swisher-decode-podcast-interview): the arsonists are not, in fact, the best firefighters.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Professor Robert Howse at the New York University School of Law tweeted that “we need to start getting the World Bank, IMF on side to establish that debtor countries w[ith] Covid-fragile economies should NOT be paying ISDS awards.” Enforcement jurisdictions, Howse argued, need to take legal actions to bar ISDS payouts. Similarly, we need major law firms to reconsider their international practices. It is difficult to imagine that corporations would sue and expect damages from governments over COVID-19 regulations without the aggressive and nauseating marketing from firms.

As a recent law graduate, I recognize that there is a role for law students and professors to play here as well. As the pandemic disrupts the fall semester and bar examinations, the legal academic community must speak up against the egregious ISDS practices. They can refuse to let ISDS profiteers recruit on-campus during the crisis. The [Me Too-related campaign](https://www.law360.com/articles/1027761/skadden-cites-metoo-in-nixing-forced-arbitration) that started on law school campuses to end the use of mandatory arbitration clauses at Orrick, Skadden, and other firms also serves as a practice guide for how law students can monitor corporate behavior.

As we reach almost 1 million deaths worldwide and 30 million COVID-19 cases, we cannot afford to let corporate lawyers weaken public health efforts. How lawyers shape their international practices over the next few weeks matters.

# Starting Your Law Career Remotely? Bridge-The-Gap Training Can Help
## Bridge-the-Gap programs offered by Practising Law Institute (PLI) help hone new attorneys’ skills – including those needed to navigate an unprecedented work environment.
By [Practising Law Institute](http://bit.ly/2LrYQ2d)  
onJanuary 20, 2021 at 1:04 PMJanuary 25, 2021 at 5:38 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/01/starting-your-law-career-remotely-bridge-the-gap-training-can-help/&text=Starting%20Your%20Law%20Career%20Remotely?%20Bridge-The-Gap%20Training%20Can%20Help)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/01/starting-your-law-career-remotely-bridge-the-gap-training-can-help/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/01/starting-your-law-career-remotely-bridge-the-gap-training-can-help/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Finding your bearings as a newly minted attorney is always challenging – and even more so during an unprecedented pandemic year. While newbies aren’t expected to be experts in all areas of law, they are expected to learn quickly, communicate effectively, and act ethically and professionally. For those working remotely, this also means learning the ropes and building relationships on a screen instead of in person.

All of this makes 2021 a particularly essential time for Bridge-the-Gap (BTG) training. Practising Law Institute (PLI) is presenting its BTG programs through two live webcasts, each focusing on ethics and skills for newly admitted New York attorneys. These programs cover topics relevant to all practice areas and settings, helping new practitioners recognize tricky ethical situations, sharpen their communications, practice negotiations, develop confidence in their pro bono toolkit, and more. Speakers include an array of established experts, including law firm partners and others from private practice, legal services organizations, in-house, executive consulting, and the bench.

Stephanie Figueroa, Program Attorney for the first half of the BTG series, [Bridge-the-Gap I: Ethics and Skills for Newly Admitted New York Attorneys](http://bit.ly/2LULOtE), uses the word “grounded” to describe PLI’s approach to developing these programs. “It comes from conscientiously and seriously thinking about newly admitted attorneys and the tasks and issues they face. What do I wish someone had taken the time to explain when I was in their shoes? What lessons did I learn the hard way that could have been avoided? We aim to make sure that the advice and guidance given is pertinent and truly useful to someone beginning their legal career.”

Communication skills can be the most challenging to bridge between the theory of law school and the practice of law. “Whether it’s learning how to negotiate with someone whose natural personality is unlike your own, or discussing difficult questions with your supervising attorney or case matter team, knowing the best way to communicate and how to handle delicate situations don’t necessarily get discussed in law school,” Figueroa notes. With an understanding that all professionals can use pointers and practice to communicate more effectively, the BTG programs emphasize “common real-world scenarios and tough situations all attorneys find themselves in at one point in time or another,” she says.

A related topic of great concern for new attorneys is how to ensure their social media presence is compatible with their ethical obligations. Jesse Sands, Program Attorney for the second half of the series, [Bridge-the-Gap II: Ethics and Skills for Newly Admitted New York Attorneys](http://bit.ly/39Ajxku), notes that “there is a natural tension between junior attorneys’ need to establish their professional brand and reputation and the sometimes-opaque ethical rules around client confidentiality, communications with represented parties, and avoiding inadvertently providing legal advice.” Promoting yourself – or even just having a normal online social life – while avoiding those ethical pitfalls “is not something that is usually covered in law school but can be the easiest ethical trap for a new attorney to fall into,” Sands adds.

Recognizing these unprecedented times, PLI also makes sure to address issues of concern for new lawyers during the “new normal” of remote work. “In BTG I, we dedicate over two hours to the ethics segment, during which the panelists will discuss the nuances of being conscientious of where you are working remotely in terms of whether you are admitted to practice law,” Figueroa says, as well as a general discussion of how to be mindful of attorney-client privilege when working remotely.

Similarly, in BTG II “our pro bono skills session includes practical advice on tackling the unique challenges of remotely representing low-income clients,” Sands says, “and our interpersonal communications segment addresses the novel challenge of how to build productive relationships with supervising attorneys in a remote environment.”

All of this might seem like a lot to take in, but Figueroa offers some key words of wisdom: “First, even the simplest tasks can become complicated if they’re done carelessly. Always reach out to a senior attorney when you have a question or need help. Finally, always remember that you’re not alone in your situation – all lawyers were newly admitted at one point! – and there are answers available to you.”

[](http://bit.ly/35Ls3ff)Practising Law Institute is a nonprofit learning organization dedicated to keeping attorneys and other professionals at the forefront of knowledge and expertise. PLI is chartered by the Regents of the University of the State of New York and was founded in 1933 by Harold P. Seligson. The organization provides the highest quality, accredited, continuing legal and professional education programs in a variety of formats which are delivered by more than 4,000 volunteer faculty including prominent lawyers, judges, investment bankers, accountants, corporate counsel, and U.S. and international government regulators. PLI publishes a comprehensive library of Treatises, Course Handbooks, Answer Books and Journals also available through the PLI PLUS online platform. The essence of PLI’s mission is its commitment to the pro bono community. View PLI’s upcoming live webcasts [here](http://bit.ly/35Ls3ff).

# Lawyers With Side Hustles Are Becoming More Commonplace In Biglaw
## How do they even find the time? Maybe hybrid work has helped.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onSeptember 27, 2023 at 12:15 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/09/lawyers-with-side-hustles-are-becoming-more-commonplace-in-biglaw/&text=Lawyers%20With%20Side%20Hustles%20Are%20Becoming%20More%20Commonplace%20In%20Biglaw)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/09/lawyers-with-side-hustles-are-becoming-more-commonplace-in-biglaw/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/09/lawyers-with-side-hustles-are-becoming-more-commonplace-in-biglaw/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Now you can work at Baker and be a baker, all at the same time!

A Biglaw job comes with Biglaw hours, but more and more lawyers are somehow finding the time to dabble in alternative careers on the side.

Have you been moonlighting as a comedian? Are you an LSAT tutor in your free time? Did you start a side gig making charcuterie boards? You are not alone — in fact, the number of attorneys with side hustles has recently risen to “astonishing” levels.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
According to a recent study from Bankrate, side hustles have become a “growing feature” of the modern workforce. The [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2023/09/27/with-flexibility-and-changing-norms-side-hustles-may-be-on-the-rise-in-big-law/) had additional details on this new trend:

The Bankrate report, which featured a YouGov poll of more than 2,500 U.S. adults—nearly 1,000 of whom claimed a “side hustle”—found 53% of Gen-Z respondents and 50% of millennial respondents earned extra cash apart from their main source of income. The numbers were 24% for baby boomers and 40% for Gen-X.

That’s also led, or at least coincided, with a shift in the mentality at big firms, away from a norm in which every last minute is devoted to clients, said [Daniel Farris, partner-in-charge of the Chicago office of Norton Rose Fulbright].

“My view is we’re beyond the days of, ‘Alright, you’re doing a two-or-three martini lunch and golfing with your clients,’ and whatever. And that actually creates time that maybe people didn’t have,” he said.

Farris himself has a side gig of sorts: as noted by Am Law, he co-founded NMBL Technologies, the company behind the legal workflow management tool Proxy. “In a considerable way,” he said, “there are more and more lawyers who are looking to have a side-hustle.”

Perhaps the option to work from home during the pandemic allowed lawyers to be more creative with their time. John McBride, a litigation partner in the IP disputes group at Norton Rose, has his own side business (he co-founded a cocktail bitters company called Devil’s Retort), and attributes lawyers’ newfound creativity to the ability to work remotely.

He said he’s still a lawyer first and foremost, and puts client and firm needs first. But “I don’t think anyone necessarily wants to be limited to their professional job description,” he said. “It may be that with flexible work arrangements, work-from-home and the like, it may be a little easier to pursue these side projects when you have a more flexible work environment.”

Are you working another job in addition to your full-time Biglaw job? Let us know, and we may feature you and your business on Above the Law (if, of course, your main gig is aware of and okay with your side gig).

# Toddler Tantrums No Match For Mom On Mission To Make Partner During Pandemic
## She says her colleagues were kind and supportive -- and no one seemed to mind when her toddler was laughing in the background.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onMarch 15, 2021 at 4:16 PMMarch 15, 2021 at 3:25 PM
4
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/toddler-tantrums-no-match-for-mom-on-mission-to-make-partner-during-pandemic/&text=Toddler%20Tantrums%20No%20Match%20For%20Mom%20On%20Mission%20To%20Make%20Partner%20During%20Pandemic)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/toddler-tantrums-no-match-for-mom-on-mission-to-make-partner-during-pandemic/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/toddler-tantrums-no-match-for-mom-on-mission-to-make-partner-during-pandemic/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
In March 2020, I found myself locked inside a tiny bathroom, participating on an important conference call while my toddler banged frantically on the other side of the door. As I tried to time my participation—including careful use of the “unmute” button—opposite his interruptions, it began to set in just how challenging trying to make partner while working remotely would be.

I was suddenly responsible for so many tasks I’d previously had more help with, including daytime childcare, cooking, and cleaning. If someone had told me then that I’d succeed in making partner at the end of the year, I would have laughed.

— [Sara E. Margolis](https://www.mololamken.com/professionals-sara-margolis), a new partner in the New York office of MoloLamken, detailing the [trials and travails she experienced](https://news.bloomberglaw.com/us-law-week/making-partner-in-a-pandemic-mololamkens-sara-e-margolis) as she attempted to [make partner at her firm during the pandemic](https://news.bloomberglaw.com/business-and-practice/young-lawyers-reveal-how-they-made-partner-in-a-pandemic).

# It's Summer Associate Season... What Do You Plan To Do With All That Cash?
## We're putting together a guide to the best products, events, and experiences you should seek out as a summer associate and we need your help.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onMay 31, 2018 at 12:01 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/05/its-summer-associate-season-what-do-you-plan-to-do-with-all-that-cash/&text=It’s%20Summer%20Associate%20Season…%20What%20Do%20You%20Plan%20To%20Do%20With%20All%20That%20Cash?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/05/its-summer-associate-season-what-do-you-plan-to-do-with-all-that-cash/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/05/its-summer-associate-season-what-do-you-plan-to-do-with-all-that-cash/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Which 5-star restaurant should I try for lunch today… it’s so hard to summer.

Graduations are behind us, and it’s now time for legions of 2Ls (mostly) to descend upon law firms around the country to garner valuable work experience, lifelong memories, and wads of cash for attending free lunches. Hopefully, along the way, [someone will do something embarrassing](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/07/can-a-summer-associate-please-blow-a-goat-or-something/) and we can all have a good laugh about it.

But what are summers planning to do with their newfound largesse? We’re putting together a “Welcome To Summering” guide with cool products, events, or excursions for summers, like a [membership to a private jet club to the Hamptons](https://blade.flyblade.com/p/blade-gx-under-28) or something, and want your input. If there’s a good deal to be had, even better! It doesn’t matter how much it costs, just that it’s something a summer should do to earn the envy of their friends back at school. If you want to [tour spooky catacombs in New York](https://www.timeout.com/newyork/things-to-do/catacombs-by-candlelight-tour), that’s a cool idea too. And if you’re no longer a summer, but have a good idea based on your experience, let us know.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
So no matter where you’re working this summer, let us know what you want to drop that summer cash on. It should go without saying, but, obviously, we’ll do this anonymously so no one knows you started your professional career tipping off Above the Law.

Just [email it to us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=Summer%20Guide) (subject line: “Summer Guide”) or hit us up with a text (646-820-8477).

[Joe Patrice](http://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/) is an editor at Above the Law and co-host of [Thinking Like A Lawyer](http://legaltalknetwork.com/podcasts/thinking-like-a-lawyer/). Feel free to [email](mailto:joe@abovethelaw.com) any tips, questions, or comments. Follow him on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/josephpatrice) if you’re interested in law, politics, and a healthy dose of college sports news.

# Meet The New Document-Comparison Solution Lawyers Are Switching To
## Draftable Legal delivers an accurate, efficient, and reliable document comparison solution for legal teams.
By DRAFTABLE  
onSeptember 27, 2023 at 11:17 AMSeptember 27, 2023 at 4:55 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/09/meet-the-new-document-comparison-solution-lawyers-are-switching-to/&text=Meet%20The%20New%20Document-Comparison%20Solution%20Lawyers%20Are%20Switching%20To)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/09/meet-the-new-document-comparison-solution-lawyers-are-switching-to/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/09/meet-the-new-document-comparison-solution-lawyers-are-switching-to/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Productivity throughout the legal industry requires reliable document-comparison software, but recent industry consolidation has reduced the options that law firms now have.

Fewer options have forced law firms around the world to reluctantly settle for existing solutions at inflated prices. But these struggles also sparked an opportunity.

Draftable, a global document-comparison provider, announced during ILTACon in August 2023 the release of [Draftable Legal](https://www.draftable.com/draftable-legal?utm_source=above-the-law&utm_medium=paid&utm_campaign=article) – a brand-new document-comparison solution made specifically for legal professionals.

The result: Law firms now have a viable alternative for their document comparison software needs.

That’s because Draftable Legal was specially designed to fill in gaps and save legal professionals time.

Commenting on the launch, Brendan McGreevy, Commercial Director at Draftable, added, “We started seeing more lawyers reaching out to us, citing three key changes in the document comparison market: sharply rising prices, eroding customer support, and dwindling product choices.

“While the legal sector has always had high demand for our general-purpose document comparison software, we weren’t always able to meet lawyers’ unique needs. So we’ve spent the past two years developing Draftable Legal directly with lawyers; and we’re thrilled to have crossed the finishing line – or the starting line, depending on how you look at it.

“The response to our launch has been overwhelmingly positive, especially with the imminent termination of Workshare and DocsCorp support!”

Draftable’s original side-by-side comparison solution gained popularity over the past decade with more than 750 global brands, notably in the finance, tech, and insurance sectors. But it wasn’t entirely suitable for the unique needs of most law firms. Recognizing this gap, the Draftable team took action.

Draftable Legal was specifically created so that lawyers, paralegals, and other legal staff can effortlessly compare and highlight key differences between multiple versions of documents. The software also boasts seamless integration with Legal Document Management Systems like iManage. The software is powered by a proprietary comparison algorithm which generates highly accurate comparisons.

[Draftable](https://www.draftable.com/?utm_source=above-the-law&utm_medium=paid&utm_campaign=article) happily serves a global clientele with a team spread across various continents and time zones, ensuring round-the-clock support, right from its headquarters in Melbourne, Australia.

Former Banking and Finance solicitor Yulia Gosper, one of Draftable Legal’s original testers, actually left her role at Herbert Smith Freehills, an international law firm, to join Draftable as a Product Specialist. Gosper went on to say: “During my time at the law firm, I’d go through loads of documents and see so many ways to boost efficiency. Draftable turned those opportunities into reality.

“Honestly, the caliber of Draftable’s team drew me in because many came from a professional-services background, making them empathetic to challenges faced by busy professionals like lawyers. I’ve seen the Draftable team repeatedly go to great lengths to understand and solve workflow-related problems experienced by our clients.”

Another recent addition to the Draftable team is Bob Moore, a legal-technology sales veteran, former VP Sales Americas at DocsCorp (provider of the CompareDocs software and acquired by Litera in 2021) and Regional Account Executive at Workshare (acquired by Litera in 2019).

When asked about joining Draftable, Moore said, “The decision was easy. I’d been part of a successful run with DocsCorp, another Aussie-run legal document-comparison company. But after seeing Draftable’s innovative product and getting to know their dynamic team, I immediately knew how successful the product was going to be, so I wanted in!”

Lauding the new additions to the team, Ben Toner, Co-founder and Chief Scientist of Draftable, stated: “We’re extremely lucky to have Bob and Yulia onboard. Their deep-rooted legal tech experience and understanding of what law firms require in software is invaluable.”

For a limited-time, Draftable Legal is offering complimentary trials to our readers, redeemable at [www.draftable.com/draftable-legal](https://www.draftable.com/draftable-legal?utm_source=above-the-law&utm_medium=paid&utm_campaign=article)

# Real Property: El Toro's Michelle Browning Coughlin
## Go behind the videoconference with the advertising technology GC, children's book author, and ATL contributor.
By [Above the Law](https://abovethelaw.com/author/above-the-law/)  
onAugust 6, 2021 at 12:17 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/real-property-el-toros-michelle-browning-coughlin/&text=Real%20Property:%20El%20Toro’s%20Michelle%20Browning%20Coughlin)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/real-property-el-toros-michelle-browning-coughlin/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/real-property-el-toros-michelle-browning-coughlin/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Even for lawyers who have largely made the switch back to the office, remote work elements remain a part of their tech stack.

Here, we visit Michelle Browning Coughlin, the GC and VP of legal affairs at the advertising technology company El Toro, who discusses her remote and on-site setups.

Our “Real Property” series includes the distractions, hobbies, and other activities that make up today’s workplace, to benchmark your own setup while gathering a few tips from your peers.

Want to share how you’ve adapted? [Click here to participate](https://breakingmedia.wufoo.com/forms/xiuybj21a48c2w/).

Describe your office decor in one sentence.

Casual and warm, welcoming, with exposed brick, hanging ivy, cute lights, and fun(ny) artwork. (My favorite is a framed quote that says, “Relax. We’re all crazy. It’s not a competition.”)

What office equipment do you use to complete your day-to-day work

Laptop, wireless mouse, [iPad](https://rstyle.me/+-97B6sBwDBUrGjAQLEynZw) with [Apple pencil](https://rstyle.me/+Xkc-BfAFBmf3EzCaJCskZA), cell phone, office chair, desk … Basic stuff! One really important thing for me — an ergonomic keyboard. I type so much that I started getting some carpal tunnel symptoms, but the [ergonomic keyboard](https://amzn.to/3fsDVI8) made a huge difference. Recently I started using the Apple pencil and I love it for taking notes in meetings and commenting on contracts. I also have to have my [wireless mouse —](https://amzn.to/3lx2WFU) I hate the built in tracker pad on laptops.

What key pieces of office furniture do you use?

Obviously a comfortable supportive office chair is important, but I spend a ton of time walking around the office and in meetings, so comfortable shoes are just as important!



What work adjacent equipment helps?

Not exactly work adjacent, but having duplicate work setups at home and in the office is super helpful. My other important work adjacent equipment is a selection of fun or inspirational coffee mugs — my latest is an RBG mug.

Any videoconference fashion must-haves?

I will admit that one of my favorite “fashion” must-haves is the “Touch Up My Appearance” feature in Zoom. Otherwise, my must-haves are just good lighting and proper camera angles. What you’re wearing is less important than proper camera placement and lighting.

I have definitely added a few new pairs of really cool earrings to my wardrobe, since that’s the jewelry that is actually visible in a videoconference.

What are your biggest meeting-bomb risks?

It used to be my husband walking behind me cleaning something … But now that I’m mostly back to working in the office, it is one of my colleague’s adorable dog (our office allows people to bring their dogs to work — so cool.)

What is your go-to publication or website for taking a breather?

I spend time checking in on Facebook to interact with my MothersEsquire community. l love to read Above the Law and Law360.

Admittedly, I am not much of a “take-a-breather” person, because any breaks in my day tend to be consumed with kid-related task, but I have recently started using Centered, an app that incorporates in small bits of meditation and stretching into your workday.

What are your favorite physical books in your background (or nearby)

Books focused on gender equity and strong women leaders (I love “[Unfinished Business](https://amzn.to/3xlt7BC)” by Anne Marie Slaughter and “[That’s What She Said](https://amzn.to/3ipL1yQ)” by Joanne Lipman), books about intellectual property, Simon Sinek’s “[The Infinite Game](https://amzn.to/37p9CNO),” and the children’s book I wrote called [“My Mom, the Lawyer.”](https://www.mothersesquire.com/buyourbook)

Please note: Occasionally, we use affiliate links on our site. This in no way affects our editorial decision-making.

# Morning Docket: 12.08.17
## * ICYMI: Texas Supreme Court Justice and Fifth Circuit nominee Don Willett saved a man from choking to death at a Chik-fil-A about a week ago. Chief Judge Stephen Dillard of the Georgia Court of Appeals had this funny little quip about Willett's heroism: "This Day in Judicial 'Activism.'" [[Houston Chronicle](http://www.chron.com/news/politics/texas/article/Willett-saves-man-s-life-performing-Heimlich-at-12392295.php)] * If you want an easy way out of your Biglaw job, just follow these easy tips for how to behave at your firm's holiday party. [[American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/sites/almstaff/2017/12/06/fire-up-a-blunt-never-work-in-big-law-again-with-these-holiday-party-tips/)] * Lanny Davis has an interesting take on all of the reasons why -- much to Donald Trump's chagrin -- the DOJ is not the president's own personal law firm. [[The Hill](http://thehill.com/opinion/judiciary/363808-doj-is-not-trumps-law-firm)] * Biglaw firms are swooping in like vultures to pick apart Sedgwick's decaying carcass. The failed firm's London office only has one partner left. [[American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/sites/americanlawyer/2017/12/07/cms-enters-fray-with-hire-of-london-sedgwick-partner/)] * "This is embarrassing, Mom. You look homeless." A Detroit lawyer has founded a nonprofit law firm and she's currently working and sleeping in an outdoor hovel during her "campout for justice." She hopes to raise money to help more clients. Here's her [GoFundMe page](https://www.gofundme.com/redetroit). Donate bonus cash to a good cause! [[Detroit Free Press](https://www.freep.com/story/news/local/michigan/detroit/2017/12/07/homeless-lawyer-camp-out-justice/922238001/)]
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onDecember 8, 2017 at 8:38 AMDecember 7, 2017 at 4:35 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2017/12/morning-docket-12-08-17/&text=Morning%20Docket:%2012.08.17)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2017/12/morning-docket-12-08-17/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2017/12/morning-docket-12-08-17/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Eat Mor Chikin’, Your Honor?

* ICYMI: Texas Supreme Court Justice and Fifth Circuit nominee Don Willett saved a man from choking to death at a Chik-fil-A about a week ago. Chief Judge Stephen Dillard of the Georgia Court of Appeals had this funny little quip about Willett’s heroism: “This Day in Judicial ‘Activism.'” [[Houston Chronicle](http://www.chron.com/news/politics/texas/article/Willett-saves-man-s-life-performing-Heimlich-at-12392295.php)]

# Reed Smith Partners Taking Another COVID-19 Financial Hit
## Austerity measures continue at this Biglaw firm.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onApril 27, 2020 at 3:05 PM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/reed-smith-partners-taking-another-covid-19-financial-hit/&text=Reed%20Smith%20Partners%20Taking%20Another%20COVID-19%20Financial%20Hit)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/reed-smith-partners-taking-another-covid-19-financial-hit/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/reed-smith-partners-taking-another-covid-19-financial-hit/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Reed Smith was early to the COVID-19 austerity measures party.[ Back in March](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/03/biglaw-firm-cuts-back-partner-compensation-amid-covid-19-economic-upheaval/?rf=1) (damn, that seems like 12 years ago), the firm announced that they were slowing partner cash distributions, emphasizing that business is good, but made the move as a “precaution” and “bracing for the short-term and potential long-term economic impacts of COVID-19.”

Well, it’s nearly a month later and the firm is making even more changes to partner compensation. After [previously announcing](https://www.law.com/international-edition/2020/04/16/reed-smith-defers-bonuses-as-withers-weightmans-furlough-staff/) that staff discretionary bonuses would be postponed due to the coronavirus — a firm spokesperson said about that measure, “We can confirm that we are deferring decisions on discretionary bonus payments for our professional staff globally. Putting these compensation changes into effect is prudent as we continue to plan for the months ahead and the pandemic’s impact on our business” — partner bonuses are, at least in part, [being deferred](https://www.law.com/international-edition/2020/04/24/shearman-offers-sabbaticals-on-30-pay-while-reed-smith-takes-more-measures/).

The firm’s equity partners’ bonuses will be split into two payments, with the first half coming on the scheduled payment date, and the balance will come three months later. The good news is that income partners, counsel, and associates will still see their full bonuses as scheduled.

From Pilot and Above The Law  
A Reed Smith spokesperson said about the latest austerity measure:

“Fixed share partner, counsel and associate bonuses will be paid in full and on their regularly scheduled pay dates. Equity partners have agreed to receive half of their bonus amounts on the regularly scheduled payment date and the remaining half three months later.”

If your firm or organization is slashing salaries, closing its doors, or reducing the ranks of its lawyers or staff, whether through open layoffs, stealth layoffs, or voluntary buyouts, please don’t hesitate to let us know. Our vast network of tipsters is part of what makes Above the Law thrive. You can [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Layoffs/Salary%20Cuts) or text us (646-820-8477).

If you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Layoff Alerts, please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the layoff alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each layoff, salary cut, or furlough announcement that we publish.

# That's A Conspiratorial Name For A Bunch Of Law Firms!
## Before sorcery, the UK dubbed their top firms like something out of a spy thriller.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onNovember 5, 2019 at 6:16 PMNovember 5, 2019 at 3:32 PM
12
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/11/thats-a-conspiratorial-name-for-a-bunch-of-law-firms/&text=That’s%20A%20Conspiratorial%20Name%20For%20A%20Bunch%20Of%20Law%20Firms!)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/11/thats-a-conspiratorial-name-for-a-bunch-of-law-firms/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/11/thats-a-conspiratorial-name-for-a-bunch-of-law-firms/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))


Before the Magic Circle, the elite UK legal landscape was a whole lot shadier. Back then, what moniker was used to describe Allen & Overy, Clifford Chance, Freshfields Bruckhaus Deringer, Herbert Smith, Linklaters, Lovells, Norton Rose, Slaughter and May, and Stephenson Harwood?

Hint: The name wasn’t the only suspicious thing either. The firms had an agreement not to poach from each other.

# There's A Big Difference Between Lawyer Accolades You Pay For And Ones You Don't
## And state bars need to be careful that this line isn't blurred.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJanuary 23, 2023 at 4:46 PMJanuary 23, 2023 at 4:21 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/01/theres-a-big-difference-between-lawyer-accolades-you-pay-for-and-ones-you-dont/&text=There’s%20A%20Big%20Difference%20Between%20Lawyer%20Accolades%20You%20Pay%20For%20And%20Ones%20You%20Don’t)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/01/theres-a-big-difference-between-lawyer-accolades-you-pay-for-and-ones-you-dont/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/01/theres-a-big-difference-between-lawyer-accolades-you-pay-for-and-ones-you-dont/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Congratulations to the 2023 UberMegaEsquires out there! Quite the honor, to be sure. To earn this award you had to rise to the top of your practice… and have your check clear. Not necessarily in that order.

Attorney awards can get a little sticky. For every organization with a solid reputation for keeping its assessment untainted by its business interests, there are others that bestow titles that raise eyebrows. State bars recognize this too, and many have promulgated rules over the past several years casting ethical judgment on attorneys advertising their services off the strength of questionable honorifics.

But these regulations introduce a whole new set of problems when they chill the celebration of deserved recognition, a development with uniquely negative repercussions for attorneys of color. Because in an industry that relies heavily on networking and connections, when attorneys without those privileges can’t tout their earned awards, it strips them of a critical avenue for distinguishing themselves to potential clients.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
[Lawyers of Color](https://lawyersofcolor.org/) president Yolanda Young explained:

Evaluating legal skills is a highly subjective endeavor, one that has been shown to be biased against [Black](https://www.findlaw.com/legalblogs/greedy-associates/confirmation-bias-against-black-associates-shown-in-memo-study/), [Asian American](https://www.winston.com/en/thought-leadership/the-broken-model-confronting-anti-asian-bias-in-the-legal-profession.html), and other lawyers of color. It is a bias that has caused an [exodus](https://news.bloomberglaw.com/business-and-practice/law-firms-struggle-to-hire-and-keep-black-women) of minorities from the profession. Even as law school classes are increasingly diverse, with people of color making up about [35%](https://www.lsac.org/blog/incoming-class-2021-most-diverse-law-school-class-history) of the 2021 entering law school class, they comprise only [14.1%](https://www.americanbar.org/groups/young_lawyers/projects/men-of-color/lawyer-demographics/) of all lawyers. Much lower percentages ever receive honors and accolades. Indeed, Lawyers of Color began bestowing such recognitions only after years of reporting on the underrepresentation of minorities receiving them. Their omissions weren’t due to a lack of credentials or accomplishments, but from the legal profession’s well-documented [biases](https://www.americanbar.org/news/abanews/aba-news-archives/2018/09/new-study-finds-gender-and-racial-bias-endemic-in-legal-professi1/).

Lawyers of Color bestows a number of [honors](https://lawyersofcolor.org/publications-2/), but the most relevant ones for this discussion are its nomination lists, which include [Nation’s Best](https://lawyersofcolor.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/Nations-Best-web.pdf), [Top Black Congressional Staffers & Lobbyists](https://lawyersofcolor.org/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/CAUCUS-ISSUE-2022-digital-v1.pdf), and the [Hot List](https://lawyersofcolor.org/wp-content/uploads/2022/12/Hot-List-2022-Digital_web-Edition-v1.pdf). All of these lists comply with the various state ethical opinions regulating attorney advertising based on lists and accolades. Young noted that the methodology behind each honor is transparent and exceeds state bar requirements, with “independent vetting review before concluding with a rigorous inquiry into attorney fitness.” Not only does the organization keep the duty of evaluating nominees separate from the fundraising side, Young informed me that, “95 percent of our honorees and their organizations have never purchased an ad or provided any other form of support.”

But a recognition is only as valuable as it is… recognized. When regulators pump out rules that leave lawyers unsure about publicizing their inclusion, it blunts the value of the honor.

From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)

[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
We continue to do this work because we believe such recognitions will maintain and increase diversity within the legal profession, which is imperative. The organizations that support us share this conviction. While state bars should require the utmost ethical standards for honors, they should take care to ensure there is no unintended and disproportionate impact on lawyers of color.

Lawyers embrace the maxim that it’s best to avoid the mere appearance of impropriety. Well, [except for the Supreme Court](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/03/clarence-thomas-is-taking-full-advantage-of-the-supreme-courts-lack-of-rules/). But generally attorneys err on the side of caution and state bars prefer to let lawyers embrace this tendency. It’s easier to keep everyone wary.

Yet, this impulse fails the profession when ethical standards impose a disparate impact on minority attorneys. When lawyers of color are left doubting if they should mention legitimate honors, it’s no longer about erring on the side of caution, it’s disadvantaging another legal professional.

It’s all well and good to stay silent on some of these rules, but this is one instance where state bars need to be proactive to make sure everyone knows exactly what is and is not allowed.

# Biglaw Partner Out Of A Job After Video Of Office Canoodling Makes The Rounds
## The video has reportedly gone viral on WhatsApp.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onAugust 16, 2021 at 1:13 PMAugust 16, 2021 at 4:13 PM
48
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/biglaw-partner-out-of-a-job-after-video-of-office-canoodling-makes-the-rounds/&text=Biglaw%20Partner%20Out%20Of%20A%20Job%20After%20Video%20Of%20Office%20Canoodling%20Makes%20The%20Rounds)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/biglaw-partner-out-of-a-job-after-video-of-office-canoodling-makes-the-rounds/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/biglaw-partner-out-of-a-job-after-video-of-office-canoodling-makes-the-rounds/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
A video clip of a Biglaw partner’s indiscretions with a colleague have gone viral. An unnamed Allen & Overy partner was caught on camera through the large glass windows of the firm’s London office in an amorous embrace — which the firm is characterizing as “inappropriate workplace conduct.” Which… points for the understatement.

The video has been making the rounds on WhatsApp, and Jamie Hamilton at[ RollOnFriday details](https://www.rollonfriday.com/news-content/exclusive-alan-all-over-me-ao-partner-quits-after-office-kneetrembler-goes-public) the footage — which was reportedly filmed months ago by a pedestrian walking through Spitalfields Market by the A&O office:

The camera zooms in to show a younger woman embracing the older, white-haired partner, who, in broad daylight, in a glass-fronted office, which opens onto a London market, proceeds to merrily move through the bases while rubbing against her.

“Oh. My. God”, remarks the cameraman, who spared audiences the worst of it by slapping a Parental Advisory sticker over the cursed footage before releasing it online. “Watch his hands, look at his hands”, mutters his companion.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
The clip sports a joking parental advisory label and the caption :

UGHHH! SOMEONE IS STAYING LATE AT THE OFFICE ???? ???? ????

Now that unnamed partner is out of a job, as RollOn Friday says, he was “permitted to resign”:

But the cost has been high for the partner, who was not supposed to be in the office at the time, and was definitely not supposed to be in the office breaching social distancing guidelines by fumbling at a youngster, and was absolutely not meant to do it all on Instagram.

Once news of his indiscretion reached the wider partnership, he was permitted to resign.

A spokesperson for Allen & Overy provided the following comment about the incident:

“The video depicts inappropriate workplace conduct which is not in line with our Code of Conduct. The matter has been investigated and addressed in line with the firm’s internal processes.”

Hopefully the lawyer will learn what is and is not acceptable at work… and that you can, in fact, see through glass.

# My Thanksgiving Objection
## It’s easy to focus on things going wrong. It’s much harder to realize that things are going right.
By [James Goodnow](https://abovethelaw.com/author/jamesgoodnow/)  
onNovember 19, 2021 at 4:16 PMAugust 31, 2022 at 5:32 PM
8
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/11/my-thanksgiving-objection/&text=My%20Thanksgiving%20Objection)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/11/my-thanksgiving-objection/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/11/my-thanksgiving-objection/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Image via Getty)

I have an objection to Thanksgiving.

My beef with Thanksgiving (pun intended) isn’t about the holiday itself or its traditions. Heck, I love the delicious jellied cranberry insanity that slides out of a can, the cross-marketing advertising blitz that is the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade, and Grandma’s green bean casserole as much as anyone does. It all warms my heart and makes me smile.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
Making Every Day A Holiday

My objection is more abstract. My problem — or fear — is that Thanksgiving has the potential to interfere with giving thanks for what we have in our lives on other days. If we focus too much on a single event, what do we do the 364 other days of the year? Having a dedicated Thanksgiving Day lets us say to ourselves, hey, we got the family together, we ate the turkey, we gave thanks. Now let’s forget about all that gratefulness for a year and get back to complaining.

Lawyers in particular love to complain. We’re literally trained to pick things apart, find flaws, and attack our adversaries, so it’s no surprise we do the same when it comes to our personal lives. Think about all of the breath and effort we spend whining about the long hours we work to earn our six- or seven-figure paychecks, or commiserating over which firm is offering more over-the-top perks than ours. We skip right past all the good things we have and hone in like a laser on the things we wish were better.

So what do we do about this? I’d challenge you this year, dear reader, to make this Thanksgiving less of a speed bump and more of a springboard toward a greater daily appreciation for all the good things you have in your life. As lawyers, we have plenty to be grateful for, and much of what’s great about our profession is as great every other month of the year as it is in November. There’s no need to time-bound our appreciation for the benefits of our way of life.

Despite the endless lawyer jokes, we remain in an overall respected profession that’s well-compensated. Each of us by default is in possession of a deeply flexible mental tool kit. We are problem solvers by nature and by training, skills that lend themselves to most situations and needs. The continued march of automation that is likely to devastate so many job spaces in the coming decade will probably not have the same, far-reaching consequences for us. Being a lawyer has its stresses and pitfalls, but if you want to have control over your world and your career, there are few better places to start than being an attorney.

I’d wager that remembering how good we have it and carrying it with us in our everyday lives would be of great benefit to most of us.

 The Special Moments

Confining our giving of thanks to Thanksgiving also risks us failing to savor those special moments in our lives. Sometimes good things happen that are big or obvious, and easy to enjoy in the moment. You land a big client or make partner. Your toddler finishes potty training. You achieve some new personal best on Peloton.

But the truly special periods of our lives can be even more subtle. Sometimes the best times of our lives are the periods when there’s just nothing major that’s wrong or stressful. Maybe most of your clients are paying their bills, you’re really into one of your cases, and you don’t have an opposing counsel going after your head. At home, maybe it’s the kids and pets haven’t needed doctor’s appointments in weeks, nothing’s broken or needing replacement, and you and your partner have found time to reconnect. Those little rare periods of peaceful bliss can be some of the happiest of our lives, while also being the hardest to recognize until they’re gone.

It’s easy to see and focus on when things go wrong. But it can be very, very hard to realize that everything’s going generally right.

Special times like this are usually transitory. They might last an evening, or a week, or a few months, and then some new major life challenge appears that sucks up our bandwidth and mental health. Most of those special times aren’t going to happen on the fourth Thursday in November. If we’re only looking for them on Thanksgiving, we’re going to miss them.

Enjoy But Don’t Forget

Please don’t take this the wrong way. Enjoy your Thanksgiving. Gather together, eat some turkey, open some vino, watch the game, and avoid talking politics. Take some time to savor a special time of the year.

But when the long weekend is over, don’t tuck those feelings of gratitude away until next November and wind yourself up to start complaining. Carry that spirit of thankfulness forward and try to recognize the good in your everyday life. Enjoy those special moments while you’re living them, and the memory will be all the sweeter.

[James Goodnow ](https://jamesgoodnow.bio/)is the CEO and managing partner of NLJ 250 firm [Fennemore Craig](https://www.fclaw.com/). At age 36, he became the youngest known chief executive of a large law firm in the U.S. He holds his JD from Harvard Law School and dual business management certificates from MIT. He’s currently attending the Cambridge University Judge Business School (U.K.), where he’s working toward a master’s degree in entrepreneurship. James is the co-author of [Motivating Millennials](http://motivatingmillennialsbook.com/), which hit number one on Amazon in the business management new release category. You can connect with James on Twitter (@JamesGoodnow) or by emailing him at [James@JamesGoodnow.com](mailto:James@JamesGoodnow.com).

# What Was The Best Biglaw Summer Associate Event Of 2016?
## What did your firm do to show love to summer associates (besides raising their pay)?
By [David Lat](https://abovethelaw.com/author/david-lat/)  
onAugust 10, 2016 at 11:47 AMAugust 15, 2016 at 6:58 PM
0
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/08/what-was-the-best-biglaw-summer-associate-event-of-2016/&text=What%20Was%20The%20Best%20Biglaw%20Summer%20Associate%20Event%20Of%202016?)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/08/what-was-the-best-biglaw-summer-associate-event-of-2016/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/08/what-was-the-best-biglaw-summer-associate-event-of-2016/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
This year was an excellent year to be a summer associate. In early June, Cravath raised associate starting salaries to [$180,000](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/breaking-ny-to-180k-cravath-raises-associate-base-salaries/), and Paul Weiss [applied the raise](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/ny-to-180k-the-raises-spread-to-summer-associates/) to summer associates. In short order, many other firms followed, paying their summers around $3,500 a week for the privilege of going to lunches at nice restaurants and otherwise having fun. (For the full tally of firms paying summer associates at the new going rate, see our [Biglaw salary scorecard](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/salary-wars-scorecard-which-firms-have-announced-raises/).)

Did Biglaw firms scale back on summer events to cover the pay raises? Anecdotal evidence suggests they did not. As far as we can tell, summer programs at law firms were just as much fun as they’ve always been.

But let’s hear from you, our readers, to get the inside scoop. It’s time for Above the Law’s annual [summer associate event contest](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/best-summer-associate-event-contest/).

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
Last year, Quinn Emanuel trounced the competition by taking summer associates on an all-expenses-paid [trip to Italy](https://abovethelaw.com/2015/08/best-summer-associate-event-contest-2015-the-winner/). But now that Quinn has [scaled back its summer program](https://abovethelaw.com/2015/06/biglaw-firm-decimates-summer-associate-program/) in favor of recruiting 3Ls and law clerks — which it woos with signing bonuses of [$35,000](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/07/biglaw-firm-offering-signing-bonus-for-3ls/) and [$75,000](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/01/clerkship-bonus-watch-will-75k-become-the-new-standard/), respectively — there’s an opening for another firm to take the crown.

So which law firm put on the best summer associate event of 2016? Please send your nominations to us [by email](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=Summer%20Associate%20Event%20Contest) (subject line: “Summer Associate Event Contest”) or by text message (646-820-8477, including the words “Summer Associate Event Contest” somewhere in your text).

We keep our tipsters anonymous. We’ll collect the best entries, let you vote on them in a reader poll, and then crown the best summer associate event of 2016. We look forward to reading all of your submissions!

# Yale Law Students Protest Paul Weiss Recruiting Event
## Students concerned about climate change demanded that the firm #DropExxon.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onFebruary 7, 2020 at 1:13 PMFebruary 7, 2020 at 12:03 PM
16
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/02/yale-law-students-protest-paul-weiss-recruiting-event/&text=Yale%20Law%20Students%20Protest%20Paul%20Weiss%20Recruiting%20Event)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/02/yale-law-students-protest-paul-weiss-recruiting-event/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/02/yale-law-students-protest-paul-weiss-recruiting-event/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Paul Weiss, you can’t hide. We can see your greedy side.

As long as you work for Exxon, we won’t work for you.

— students at Yale Law School yelled these chants [during a Paul Weiss boycott outside the firm’s first-year recruitment reception](https://biglawbusiness.com/exxon-climate-law-firm-paul-weiss-target-of-protest-at-yale) at the elite school yesterday. Students are targeting Paul Weiss for its representation of ExxonMobil, claiming that the firm has aided the oil and gas company in “decades of disinformation to obstruct climate action.” Last month, students at [Harvard Law protested at a Paul Weiss recruitment event](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/01/harvard-law-school-students-protest-paul-weiss-recruiting-event/), demanding that the firm drop Exxon as a client.

# Morning Docket: 09.19.23
## * Rudy Giuliani sued by attorney over $1.36 million in legal fees. That's about [4200 Cameos](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/rudy-giuliani-tries-to-pay-mounting-legal-fees-one-awkward-birthday-greeting-at-a-time/) for the guy. [[NBC](https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/politics-news/giuliani-sued-former-lawyers-claiming-14-million-unpaid-legal-fees-rcna105731)] * Weil, O'Melveny and Keker, Van Nest & Peters among firms sorting out the remains of the Pac-12. [[American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/2023/09/15/turmoil-in-the-ncaas-power-five-means-business-for-big-law/)] * Internet "protect the children!" laws to restrict content are unconstitutional on a bipartisan basis. [[Washington Post](https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2023/09/18/california-online-child-safety-law/)] * Meanwhile, loot boxes aimed at kids? Yeah, those are trouble. [[LegalCheek](https://www.legalcheek.com/lc-journal-posts/why-we-need-to-take-a-closer-look-at-loot-boxes/)] * Perkins Coie and MoFo hire counsel in pending DEI suits. Perkins hired Jenner & Block (and boutique firm Lynn Pinker Hurst & Schwegmann) and MoFo has hired MoFo has hired Gibson Dunn (and boutique firm Gelber Schachter & Greenberg). [[Bloomberg Law News](https://news.bloomberglaw.com/business-and-practice/perkins-coie-morrison-foerster-lawyer-up-for-dei-lawsuits)] * David Boies charges $2110 an hour. Pro tip: it's best to write down all your questions for your attorney beforehand to streamline the meeting! [[Reuters](https://www.reuters.com/legal/legalindustry/david-boies-reveals-2110-billing-rate-deutsche-bank-fee-bid-2023-09-18/)] * Winner, winner, market-manipulated chicken dinner. [[Law360](https://www.law360.com/articles/1722956/sanderson-was-chicken-price-fixing-ringleader-jury-told)]
By [Above the Law](https://abovethelaw.com/author/above-the-law/)  
onSeptember 19, 2023 at 8:56 AMSeptember 20, 2023 at 11:13 AM
4
